介绍

Introduction

在1991 年，上海决定修建地铁时，世界银行指责上海“在没有研究所有可能的替代方案的情况下就选择了地铁这种昂贵的系统”。毕竟，上海是一个拥有 650 万辆自行车和不到 20 万辆机动车的城市，其中大部分是商用卡车和公共汽车。那么，改善自行车基础设施是否对这座城市更有利呢？“这种昂贵的交通方式能否成为城市客运系统的核心，值得怀疑，”世界银行总结道。

In 1991, when Shanghai decided to build a subway, the World Bank scolded it for “opting for such an expensive system as metro without studying all possible alternatives.” This was, after all, a city of 6.5 million bicycles and less than 200,000 motor vehicles, most of which were commercial trucks and buses. Might the city be better off improving its bike infrastructure instead? “It is doubtful that such an expensive mode can be the core to the urban transport system for passengers,” the bank concluded.

上海还是决定修建地铁。事实上，早在 25 年前，该市就已经开始修建地铁系统。1964 年，其隧道工程局在法租界衡山公园地下深处开挖了一条 2100 英尺长的隧道和地铁站原型。几年后，由于文化大革命的混乱，该项目被搁置，但 1990 年 1 月，国务院批准了一项新计划，工作重新开始。

Shanghai decided to build a subway anyway. In fact, the city had already broken ground on a system a quarter-century earlier when, in 1964, its Tunnel Engineering Bureau dug a prototype 2,100-foot tunnel and metro station deep below Hengshan Park in the French Concession. The project was shelved a few years later amid the mayhem of the Cultural Revolution, but in January 1990 the State Council greenlit a fresh plan, and work began anew.

上海地铁项目是一项重大公共工程合同，来自十几个国家的公司竞相参与建设。在接下来的五年里，10,000 名工人在上海的黏土般的隧道中钻孔土壤。“上海似乎渴望参与 《纽约时报》写道：“我们必须赶上世界其他国家。 ”

The Shanghai subway project represented a major public works contract, and firms from a dozen countries bid to have a hand in building it. For the next five years, 10,000 workers bored through Shanghai’s claylike soil. “Shanghai, it seems, is eager to play catch-up with the rest of the world,” wrote the New York Times.

事实确实如此。1995 年 4 月 10 日，上海开通了第一条地铁线路，这是一条最先进的十英里长的隧道和十三座车站。在人民广场站，官员们铺上了红地毯。一位香港开发商惊叹道，这一灵活的流程“实际上比美国更少官僚主义”。上海对自己的实力充满信心，制定了一个雄心勃勃的目标，即到 2045 年将地铁系统扩展到 200 英里的轨道，而这距离未来整整五十年的时间还很远。

That it was. On April 10, 1995, Shanghai inaugurated its first full metro line, a state-of-the-art ten miles of tunnel and thirteen stations. At the People’s Square stop, officials unfurled a red carpet. One Hong Kong developer marveled that the nimble process was “actually less bureaucratic” than in the United States. Agog at its own strength, Shanghai set the ambitious goal of expanding the system to two hundred miles of track by 2045, a full fifty years in the future.

它比自己设定的期限提前了几十年。如今，上海地铁全长超过 400 英里，是世界上最长的地铁系统，每年运送乘客超过 30 亿人次。

It beat its own deadline by decades. Today, over 400 miles in length, the Shanghai Metro is the world’s longest subway system, carrying more than three billion passengers each year.

这类庞大的基础设施项目已成为中国不可阻挡的营销手段。四十年前，中国的交通基础设施覆盖率是世界上最稀疏的。如今，近 250 万英里的道路遍布各省。2011 年，中国高速公路的长度超过了美国州际公路系统。世界前 20 个集装箱港口中有 10 个在中国，其中最大的一个位于上海。2015 年，政府宣布打算在未来五年内建造 40 个新机场。这种急于求成的心态也推动了私营部门的发展。去年，长沙一家房地产公司开发商他在十九天内建造了一座五十七层的摩天大楼，仅仅因为他能做到。

These kinds of colossal infrastructure projects have become marketing devices for China’s unstoppability. Forty years ago, the country’s transportation infrastructure coverage was among the sparsest in the world. Today, nearly 2.5 million miles of roads branch out across its provinces. In 2011, the length of China’s expressways surpassed the U.S. Interstate Highway System’s. Ten of the world’s top twenty container ports are in China, including the biggest, in Shanghai. In 2015, the government announced its intention to build forty new airports in the next five years. This breakneck mentality propels the private sector as well. Last year, a Changsha-based real estate developer built a fifty-seven-story skyscraper in nineteen days, simply because he could.

这些项目中最引人瞩目的是中国的高铁系统，该系统仅用了大约十年的时间建成，比世界上任何其他高铁系统都要大。2008 年 8 月 1 日，即北京夏季奥运会开幕式前几天，高铁网络的首趟列车从北京开往天津。八年后，中国铁路宣布其高铁网络已超过 20,000 公里，并预计到 2030 年将超过 45,000 公里。

The crown jewel of these ventures is China’s high-speed rail system, constructed in the space of about a decade, and bigger than any other high-speed system in the world. The network’s first train rolled from Beijing to Tianjin on August 1, 2008, days before the opening ceremonies of the Summer Games in Beijing. Eight years later, China Railway announced its high-speed network had surpassed the 20,000 kilometer mark, then projected it to extend beyond 45,000 kilometers by 2030.

自那时起，中国最引人瞩目的铁路建设甚至都不在中国国内。中国经济战略的一大重点就是在境外建设基础设施。其中许多建设都属于“一带一路”计划。中国计划通过一个互联互通的公路、铁路、机场和海港网络，将半个地球纳入自己的轨道。这个计划已经成为了自己的品牌——在我乘坐国泰航空飞往香港的航班上，后排电视播放着中国银行的广告，介绍如何将我与“一带一路”机遇联系起来。曼谷的高速公路广告牌和万象的​​头版新闻都刊登了这一广告。从“一带一路”地图上看，箭头纵横交错，从亚洲到非洲再到欧洲。这些路线沿途的许多国家无法自己建设这样的基础设施，因此将中国帮助它们建设基础设施视为跃升发展链的机会。

Since then, China’s most visible railway endeavors haven’t even been in China itself. A major thrust of the country’s economic strategy involves building infrastructure beyond its own borders. Many of these efforts fall under its One Belt One Road initiative, China’s plan to pull half the globe into its orbit with an interconnected network of roads, rail, airports, and seaports. The plan has become its own brand—on my Cathay Pacific flight to Hong Kong, the seatback TV played Bank of China ads offering to connect me to “One Belt One Road opportunities.” It’s on freeway billboards in Bangkok and front-page news in Vientiane. Maps of the initiative show arrows criss-crossing the earth, from Asia to Africa to Europe. Many of the countries in the path of these routes can’t build such infrastructure themselves, and see China’s offers to build it for them as a chance to leapfrog up the development chain.

“一带”是指丝绸之路经济带，是一条从中国延伸到西欧的陆上基础设施、供应链和贸易路线网络。“一路”是指二十一世纪海上丝绸之路，即横跨印度洋、波斯湾和地中海的海上航线网络。总而言之，这是一个超现实的计划，即使对中国来说也是如此。然而，与其说这是一个有凝聚力的计划，不如说是一个资金充足的想法，可以以各种方式实现。它包括为交通、能源和城市化项目提供资金支持，以及建立经济伙伴关系和放开跨境贸易的授权。它也是为了平衡美国在该地区的影响而发展起来的，也是一个营销口号，旨在将中国打造为世界首屈一指的全球开发商。

The “Belt” refers to the Silk Road Economic Belt, an overland network of infrastructure, supply chains, and trading routes stretching from China to Western Europe. The “Road” is the Twenty-first Century Maritime Silk Road, a web of shipping lanes traversing the Indian Ocean, Persian Gulf, and Mediterranean Sea. Taken together, it’s a scheme of surreal scope, even for China. Yet it’s not a cohesive plan so much as a well-funded idea that could manifest in various ways. It includes pools of financial backing for transport, energy, and urbanization projects, and a mandate to form economic partnerships and liberalize cross-border trade. It’s also evolved as a bid to counterbalance American influence in the region, and a marketing slogan to brand China as the world’s premiere global developer.

尽管“一带一路”计划直到 2013 年才由中国国家主席习近平正式启动，但这一计划已迅速成为该国的标志性举措。2016 年 2 月，一列货运列车首次从中国驶往伊朗，全程 6,462 英里，穿越石油和天然气资源丰富的中亚地区。在印度次大陆，中国正在建设一条公路、铁路和能源基础设施走廊，将巴基斯坦海岸与中国西部新疆连接起来。“一带一路”目前包括中国国有企业收购的土耳其海港、白俄罗斯的工业园区以及从内罗毕到肯尼亚海岸的铁路。“一带一路”计划涵盖 60 多个国家，投资超过一万亿美元，旨在将中国打造为全球商业活动的中心。

Though only officially launched by Chinese President Xi Jinping in 2013, the effort has quickly become the country’s marquee initiative. In February 2016, a freight train rolled from China to Iran for the first time, a 6,462-mile journey through oil- and gas-rich Central Asia. On the Indian Subcontinent, China is developing a corridor of roads, rail, and energy infrastructure linking Pakistan’s coast to the western Chinese territory of Xinjiang. One Belt One Road now includes a Turkish seaport bought by Chinese state-owned companies, an industrial park in Belarus, and a railway from Nairobi to the Kenyan coast. Encompassing more than sixty countries and over a trillion dollars in spending, the Belt and Road Initiative is an endeavor to make China an epicenter of global commercial activity.

对中国来说，这只是回归自然秩序，结束了长期尴尬的连败，而这种连败本来就不应该发生。这就是习近平所说的“中国梦”——而不是赫伯特·胡佛曾说过“家家户户都有鸡，家家户户都有车”，但这是一个不容忽视的“中央王国”的回归。正如中国位于北京外交部悬挂的世界地图的中心一样，“一带一路”是一项旨在恢复中国全球中心地位的计划，其全球贸易的硬件遍布亚洲、非洲和欧洲，最终都流回中华人民共和国。

As far as China is concerned, this is simply a return to the natural order, the end of a long and embarrassing losing streak that shouldn’t have occurred in the first place. This is what Xi means when he talks about the “Chinese Dream”—not Herbert Hoover’s “a chicken in every pot and a car in every garage,” but the return of a Middle Kingdom to be reckoned with. Just as China sits at the center of the world map that hangs in Beijing’s Foreign Ministry, One Belt One Road is a plan to reclaim the country’s global centrality, with the hardware of its worldwide trade stretching across Asia, Africa, and Europe, all of it ultimately flowing back to the People’s Republic.

该计划的众多触角之一看起来触手可及。

One of the initiative’s many tentacles looks tantalizingly within reach.

泛亚铁路最初是在 1995 年东盟峰会上提出的，是一条连接中国和新加坡的区域性铁路网。由于政治分歧和资金短缺，该项目一直停滞不前，直到 21 世纪初，当时已成为全球发展领导者的中国才开始努力推动该项目。就像“一带一路”一样，泛亚铁路更像是一个想法，而不是一个有凝聚力的计划，拟议的线路根据其经过的国家而具有不同的用途。这是一个零碎的过程，通过逐一达成的双边协议慢慢展开，因此其外交障碍至少与其实际建设一样艰巨。

The Pan-Asia Railway was first proposed at the 1995 ASEAN Summit as a regionwide network of rail connections running from China to Singapore. Political disagreements and a lack of funds stalled the project until the early 2000s when China, by then a leader in global development, began making efforts to jump-start it. Like One Belt One Road itself, the Pan-Asia Railway is more an idea than a cohesive plan, with proposed links serving different purposes depending on the country they run through. It’s a piecemeal process slowly unfolding through bilateral agreements hammered out case by case, making its diplomatic hurdles at least as daunting as its actual construction.

这条铁路将始于云南省会昆明，而云南是中国与东南亚的边界。中国计划从昆明向南延伸，穿过废弃的城市磨丁进入老挝，然后穿过老挝半岛、泰国和马来西亚，最后到达新加坡岛。

The railway would begin in Kunming, capital of Yunnan, the far southwestern province that forms China’s border with Southeast Asia. From there, China envisions the tracks diving southward, crossing into Laos at the abandoned city of Boten, and working its way down the peninsula through Laos, Thailand, and Malaysia, before terminating on the island of Singapore.

一个多世纪以来，从中国开通到新加坡的火车概念一直在酝酿之中。1904 年，西伯利亚大铁路将莫斯科与太平洋连接起来，不久之后，英国和法国殖民者开始考虑修建自己的大铁路，将他们在印度支那半岛的热带地区连接起来。如果不是西贡和金边之间缺少一节连接线，他们几乎实现了这一梦想，修建了一条米轨铁路，这条铁路将一直从昆明延伸到新加坡。但当殖民势力离开时，统一该地区的意愿也随之消失，这证明铁路梦想不仅是为了提供交通，也是为了巩固帝国。

The notion of a train from China to Singapore has been on the drawing board for over a century. In 1904, the Trans-Siberian Railway connected Moscow to the Pacific, and soon afterward, British and French colonists began pondering their own grand railroad that would weave together their tropical trophies on the Indochina peninsula. They came close to realizing the dream with a meter-gauge track that would have run all the way from Kunming to Singapore if not for a missing link between Saigon and Phnom Penh. But when the colonial powers departed, the will to unify the region left with them, proving the railway dream was always as much about fortifying an empire as providing transportation.

整个二十世纪，东南亚的殖民铁路英勇前行，逐渐瓦解，有时甚至被炸成碎片。与此同时，中国把自己遥远的省份连接起来拥有庞大的铁路网，保罗·索鲁将之称为“铁公鸡”。对于中国来说，那是一段沉闷的时期。鸦片战争的失败使它陷入了长期的恶劣情绪，中国自己称之为“百年屈辱”，在此期间，占主导地位的外国列强要求中国做出让步，这实际上是将中国国家主权的一部分转让给西方对手。上海、广州和其他中国港口被迫开放对外贸易，英国国民在中国逗留期间被授予治外法权。在中国的主要城市，西方和日本列强建立了孤立的定居点，通过艾波卡特风格的家园复制品将自己与中国社会隔离开来。

Throughout the twentieth century, the colonial railways of Southeast Asia heroically trundled along, gradually falling apart and occasionally bombed to bits. Meanwhile, China knitted together its own far-flung provinces with a massive network of tracks Paul Theroux dubbed the Iron Rooster. It was a dreary time for the Middle Kingdom. Its losses in the Opium Wars had plunged it into a prolonged foul mood that China itself called its “Century of Humiliation,” a period during which dominant foreign powers demanded concessions that essentially transferred elements of Chinese national sovereignty to its Western adversaries. Shanghai, Guangzhou, and other Chinese ports were forced to open to foreign trade, and British subjects were granted extraterritoriality privileges while staying in China. In major Chinese cities, Western and Japanese powers established insular settlements, isolating themselves from Chinese society in Epcot-style replicas of home.

百年屈辱成为一种激励的燃料，最终被共产党用来煽动民族主义对国家强大和增长的承诺。一带一路就是这一承诺的具体体现，泛亚铁路也是如此，它将把中国与东南亚那些在实力上远远超过它的新兴国家连接起来。其中一些国家，如泰国和马来西亚，拥有日益壮大的渴望中国出口产品的消费阶层。缅甸等其他国家则向中国输送玉石和天然气等资源。其中许多国家都拥有战略位置优越的海港。还有一些国家有潜力成为房地产前沿，中国开发商可以在那里建造城市，吸引中国侨民蜂拥而至。作为获得准入的回报，中国提供了一笔千载难逢的交易：一笔可观的资金从现在到 2030 年，亚洲发展中国家每年需要建设 1.7 万亿美元的基础设施。

The Century of Humiliation became a motivating propellant, eventually used by the Communist Party to whip up a nationalistic commitment to strengthening and growth. One Belt One Road is this commitment made manifest, as is the Pan-Asia Railway, which would fuse China with the Southeast Asian up-and-comers it has far surpassed in power. Some of these countries, like Thailand and Malaysia, have growing consumer classes hungry for Chinese exports. Others, like Myanmar, funnel resources like jade and natural gas to China. Many of them have strategically located seaports. Others have potential as real estate frontiers where Chinese developers can build cities to which Chinese expats can flock. In return for the access, China is offering what amounts to a once-in-a-lifetime deal: a significant chunk of the annual $1.7 trillion in infrastructure developing Asia needs to build between now and 2030.

没有哪个国家比老挝的基础设施更少。由于地理位置的缘故，这个共产主义小国发现自己处于这场闹剧的中心，而北方边境的这个大国正在请求允许通过。老挝拥有丰富的自然资源，如木材和矿产——这些资源可以通过铁路用火车运回中国。老挝的水资源也十分丰富。湄公河及其支流滋养着老挝的农场和水电站，人均水资源比亚洲任何其他国家都要多。

No country has less of this infrastructure than Laos. By fate of geography, the tiny communist state finds itself at the center of the drama, with the giant on its northern border requesting permission to barrel through. Laos is awash in natural resources like timber and minerals—resources a railway could haul back to China by the trainload. It also has an abundance of water. The Mekong River and its tributaries nurture Laos’s farms and hydropower plants with more water resources per capita than any other country in Asia.

老挝很少受到重视，当奥巴马总统 2016 年访问时，美国驻万象大使馆花了一年时间精心准备他的到访。老挝最对泛亚铁路的宝贵贡献可能仅仅是一条向南的道路。“长期以来老挝的一个特点是它的地理位置使它总是易受外界影响，”弗兰克·艾伯特 (Frank Albert) 说，他是美国国务院前官员，曾在 20 世纪 60 年代在老挝工作，与该国保持着私人联系。法国殖民者将老挝视为阻挡英国人的缓冲区。越南人用它作为抵御中国人的堡垒。美国视老挝为阻止共产主义蔓延到泰国的防火墙，越共将老挝用作向南越军队运送物资的中转站。美国外交关系委员会高级研究员、该地区研究权威约书亚·科兰齐克在其著作《 一个适合打仗的地方》中写道，德怀特·艾森豪威尔非常执着于将老挝作为阻止共产主义蔓延的屏障，他警告约翰·F·肯尼迪，老挝安全是世界上最紧迫的外交政策问题。

So rarely regarded is Laos that when President Obama visited in 2016 the U.S. Embassy in Vientiane spent a year meticulously preparing for his drop in. Laos’s most valuable contribution to the Pan-Asia Railway might simply be a path southward. “The quality that has long defined Laos is how its location has always made it susceptible to outside influences,” says Frank Albert, a former U.S. State Department official who worked in Laos in the 1960s and maintains personal ties to the country. French colonialists saw Laos as a buffer to hold back the British. The Vietnamese used it as a bulwark against the Chinese. The U.S. saw it as a firewall to keep communism from spilling into Thailand, and the Viet Cong used Laos as a pass-through to shuttle supplies to its troops in South Vietnam. In his book A Great Place to Have a War, Joshua Kurlantzick, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and a leading authority on the region, writes that Dwight D. Eisenhower was so obsessed with Laos as a barrier to communism’s spread that he warned John F. Kennedy that its security was the most pressing foreign policy issue in the world.

如今，老挝的地理位置再次使其成为一个值得接触的地方，中国经常派代表前往那里，承诺诱人，威胁微妙。“这几乎是一种一呼一应的关系，”布莱恩·艾勒说，他曾在中国工作十五年，目前担任华盛顿智库史汀生中心东南亚项目主任。“我们真的不确定结果会怎样。但我们可以肯定的是，中国不会消失。”

Now Laos’s location has once again made it a place worth engaging, a place to which China has routinely dispatched delegates bearing enticing promises and subtle threats. “It’s almost a call-and-response thing,” says Brian Eyler, who spent fifteen years working in China and is now director of the Southeast Asia program at the Stimson Center, a Washington think tank. “We’re not really sure what the outcome will be. What we’re sure of is that China is not going away.”

欢迎来到老挝拉斯维加斯

Welcome to Laos Vegas

皇家景兰酒店外形呈回旋镖状，漆成金色，像一双张开的手臂一样俯瞰着小城磨丁。几年前，抵达的客人大多是中国人，他们沿着红地毯走进烟雾缭绕的大堂，在左边的接待处排队。办理入住手续后，许多人迅速走向赌场的百家乐赌桌。其他人则被妓女拦住，她们挨家挨户推销自己的服务。酒店门前，有轨电车停在喷泉附近，等着将客人送往这座城市热闹的廉价酒吧、天鹅绒绳索夜总会，以及出售中国春药和盗版 DVD 的街头小贩。

The Royal Jingland Hotel, boomerang-shaped and painted gold, presided over the tiny city of Boten like a pair of arms spread wide. Years ago, arriving guests, mostly Chinese, followed a red carpet into its smoky lobby and queued up at a reception desk to the left. After checking in, many quickly made their way to the baccarat tables in the casino. Others were intercepted by the prostitutes who went room to room pitching their services. Out front, electric trams idled near the fountain, waiting to shuttle guests to the city’s throbbing dive bars, velvet-rope nightclubs, and street vendors selling Chinese aphrodisiacs and pirated DVDs.

这家拥有 270 个房间的酒店在磨丁这个浮华的小王国里非常有名，那里有俱乐部、毒品、赌场、妓女和各种小规模和有组织的犯罪活动。赌博在中国是非法的，磨丁在技术上战胜了这一麻烦，因为它位于老挝边境对面。但尽管它位于老挝，磨丁本质上是一个中国城市。中国公民享受宽松的签证要求，几乎构成了全部劳动力。在磨丁的商店门前，操着云南口音的叫卖者叫卖着仿制的 Jimmy Choo 高跟鞋。街道上巡逻的不是老挝警察，而是中国雇佣的安全部队。甚至连时钟都调到了北京时间，比万象早一个小时。（从泰国乘坐巴士来的变性人是唯一的异类。）

The 270-room hotel was well known in Boten’s gaudy little kingdom of clubs, drugs, casinos, hookers, and crime both petty and organized. Gambling is illegal in China, a nuisance that Boten beat on a technicality by existing just over the border in Laos. But though it was in Laos, Boten was essentially a Chinese city. Chinese nationals enjoyed relaxed visa requirements, and constituted virtually the entire labor force. In front of Boten’s shops, barking vendors with Yunnanese accents hawked replica Jimmy Choo pumps. The streets were patrolled not by Laotian police but by security forces on China’s payroll. Even the clocks were set to Beijing time, an hour ahead of Vientiane. (The ladyboys, bused in from Thailand, provided the only heterogeneity.)

磨丁面积只有六平方英里，比纽约的约翰·肯尼迪机场略小，它本身就是中国进口的，这得益于磨丁经济特区的支持。2003 年，中国政府与老挝计划投资部联合建立了这个经济特区，实际上把磨丁整个地区都交给了中国。原本居住在那里的老挝村民很快就被搬迁到几英里外的地方，一家名为福兴公司的香港开发公司获得了开发这座城市的三十年租约。当时的一份外交电报显示美国国务院怀疑该公司可能是磨丁主要投资者黄明贤的“幌子公司”。黄明贤是福建商人，据说与缅甸一家类似的赌场企业有联系。他花费数千万美元在老挝荒野建造了这个肮脏的赌博前哨。一本小册子将磨丁描述为“隐藏在茂密丛林中的黄金之地，就像彼得潘永不倒塌的城市，就像神秘的宝藏岛。”旅游杂志上的一则广告称磨丁是“老挝最国际化的现代化城市”，这与事实相差无几，尽管它完全是由另一个国家现代化的。

A mere six square miles, or a bit smaller than New York’s John F. Kennedy Airport, Boten itself was a Chinese import, made possible under the auspices of the Boten Special Economic Zone. The SEZ, established jointly in 2003 between the Chinese government and the Laos Ministry of Planning and Investment, effectively handed Boten to China in its entirety. The Lao villagers who originally lived there were quickly relocated several miles down the road, and a development entity called the Fok Hing Company from Hong Kong acquired a thirty-year lease to develop the city. A diplomatic cable from the time indicates that the U.S. State Department suspected this company might be “a front organization” for Boten’s principal investor, a Mr. Huang Ming Xian. A Fujianese businessman with reported links to a similar casino enterprise in Myanmar, Huang spent tens of millions of dollars building the sleazy gambling outpost in the Lao wilderness. One brochure described Boten as “a golden place hiding in the luxuriant jungles, just like Peter Pan’s city of never falling down, just like mysterious treasure island.” An ad in a tourism magazine called it the “most internationally modernized city in Laos,” which wasn’t far from the truth, though it was modernized by another country entirely.

几年来，磨丁的华丽娱乐活动吸引了成千上万的中国游客。但随着时间的推移，这座城市的古色古香开始褪色。节目。老挝移民官员不堪重负，开始失去对边境的控制，因为不守规矩的游客认为磨丁是中国的私人财产，他们会从云南省肆无忌惮地闯过检查站，他们的越野车在未经检查的情况下飞驰进入老挝，扬起尘土。无法弥补损失的赌徒开始消失，2009 年，中国湖北省的官员赶到边境，谈判释放被关在一家赌场后面的一群中国游客。小巷里开始出现带有枪伤的尸体，谣言四起，说磨丁周围的山上到处都是浅坟。

For several years, Boten’s garish amusements attracted thousands of Chinese tourists. But as the decade wore on, the city’s patina began to show. Overwhelmed Lao immigration officials started losing their grip on the border as unruly visitors, rightly thinking of Boten as China’s personal property, would blow through the checkpoint from Yunnan province with impunity, their SUVs kicking up dust as they sped into Laos uninspected. Gamblers who couldn’t make good on their losses began vanishing, and in 2009, officials from China’s Hubei province rushed to the border to negotiate the release of a group of Chinese tourists held hostage in the back of one of the casinos. Corpses with gunshot wounds began turning up in alleys, and rumors spread that the hills around Boten were filled with shallow graves.

最终，2010 年，中国外交部不得不警告游客不要去磨丁的不良场所，这终结了磨丁存在的唯一理由。第二年 3 月，北京决定不再享受乐趣，取消了对中国公民的签证豁免。它甚至切断了磨丁的电力和手机信号。一个月后，皇家景兰酒店卷起红地毯，将有轨电车停在大楼后面的杂草丛中，并在门上装上自行车锁。

Finally, in 2010, the Chinese foreign ministry had to warn tourists to avoid Boten’s unsavory venues, terminating the town’s only reason for existing. In March the next year, Beijing decided the fun was over and ended the visa exemption for Chinese citizens. It even cut the city’s power and cell phone signal. One month later, the Royal Jingland Hotel rolled up its red carpet, parked the trams in the weeds behind the building, and slapped a bike lock on its doors.

这座城市荒谬的崛起和衰落成为中国高速增长的另一个奇怪的副产品。但磨丁最初并不是一座赌城。磨丁黄金城原本应该成为其官方名称所暗示的那样：一个可以作为中国进入东南亚门户的经济特区。最初的计划包括一个贸易中心、一个制造综合体和仓储设施——这是连接邻近地区经济体的中转站的基础设施支持。磨丁未能充分利用其唯一的优势——边境口岸，将世界上最强大的国家之一与最弱小的国家之一连接起来，就倒闭了。

The city’s ridiculous rise and collapse became another curious byproduct of China’s hyperactive growth. But Boten was not originally meant to be just a gambling town. Boten Golden City was supposed to be exactly what its official designation suggested: a special economic zone that could function as China’s gateway into Southeast Asia. The original plans included a trading center, a manufacturing complex, and storage facilities—the infrastructural support for a waystation linking neighboring regional economies. Boten collapsed before it could fully cash in on the one thing it had going for it—its border crossing, connecting one of the world’s most powerful nations to one of the least.

过了磨丁过境点，老挝 3 号公路的起点就到了。几十年来，3 号公路一直是一条破旧的柏油路，而在此之前，这条路是一条鸦片走私路线。只要你有足够的毅力、时间，并且驾驶四轮驱动车，你就可以沿着这条路穿过老挝的群山，直抵泰国边境。如果你愿意，你可以继续前往曼谷，沿着碧绿的海岸继续行驶，进入马来西亚，穿过吉隆坡，最后到达新加坡市中心。

Just beyond the Boten border crossing is the beginning of Route 3 in Laos. For decades, Route 3 was a crumbling blacktop, and before that, an opium smuggling trail. With fortitude, time, and four-wheel drive, you could follow this road straight through Laos’s mountains to the Thai border. If you wanted, you could continue to Bangkok, keep driving down the turquoise coast into Malaysia and right through Kuala Lumpur, and end up in downtown Singapore.

21 世纪初，3 号公路所属的道路网络被重建、重铺，并 泰国政府对该项目进行了现代化改造。亚洲开发银行负责管理该项目并提供贷款，但中国将从改善的交通中受益，直接资助了大部分项目。 《人民日报》 报道称，“中国将修建连接中国和泰国的高速公路”。2002 年，新闻标题根本就没有提到这条公路实际上经过的国家——老挝。

In the early 2000s, the network of roads to which Route 3 belongs were rebuilt, resurfaced, and modernized. The Asian Development Bank managed the project and provided the loans, but China, which stood to benefit from the improved access, directly financed chunks of it. “China to Build Highway to Link China and Thailand,” reported the People’s Daily in 2002, the headline failing to even mention little Laos, the country the road would actually run through.

为了将自己的城市接入该网络，中国还斥资 40 亿美元改造了昆明至磨丁的公路，该公路的状况几乎与 3 号公路一样糟糕一名云南官员开玩笑说，当他们到达老挝边境时，“一半人都在呕吐”。工人们炸毁了道路穿越喜马拉雅山麓。一段险峻的路段需要架设 430 座桥梁。最终，这条 1,150 英里长的沥青河一直流到曼谷。

To connect its own cities to this network, China also spent $4 billion improving the road from Kunming to Boten, which was in nearly as poor condition as Route 3 itself. “Half the people were throwing up” by the time they arrived at the Laos border, joked one Yunnan official. Workers blasted the road through the Himalayan foothills. One treacherous stretch required 430 bridges. When all was said and done, the 1,150-mile river of asphalt flowed all the way to Bangkok.

这是中国较早的实力壮举之一，宣告中国进入东南亚，此后几年，中国在东南亚地区的存在感将日益增强。1992 年，柬埔寨、老挝、泰国、缅甸、越南和中国云南和广西地区之间的贸易额每年达到 370 亿美元。2005年，这一数字激增至1540亿美元。

It was one of China’s earlier feats of strength, announcing the country’s arrival in Southeast Asia, a region in which its presence would grow increasingly visible in the years that followed. In 1992, trade between Cambodia, Laos, Thailand, Myanmar, Vietnam, and the Chinese regions of Yunnan and Guangxi amounted to $37 billion annually. By 2005, it had exploded to $154 billion.

至于小小的磨丁，它之所以能以狂欢派对小镇而闻名，纯粹是因为它是昆曼高速公路上第一个东南亚村庄。2011 年中国撤离这座城市后，磨丁就成了一个没有目的的地方。这里仅存的几位居民骑着摩托车在空荡荡的街道上穿梭。有些人经营着建在昔日旅游陷阱两侧的铁皮店，店里的中文招牌暴露了磨丁最初开拓者的身份。午后的阳光下，他们会在一家名为 Super Star 的废弃夜总会的水泥亭子上晒玉米。这家夜总会本身是玉米黄色的，正面是烟熏玻璃窗、科林斯柱，还有晒得褪色的海报，上面画着年轻漂亮的中国狂欢者喝着看起来很昂贵的鸡尾酒，享受着人生的美好时光。

As for little Boten, its brush with fame as a swinging party town had occurred purely by luck of location as the first Southeast Asian village on the Kunming-Bangkok Expressway. When China walked away from the city in 2011, Boten became a place without a purpose. Its few remaining residents buzzed through the empty streets on sputtering motorbikes. Some ran tin-box shops built into the sides of the former tourist traps, their Mandarin signage betraying the identities of Boten’s original pioneers. In the afternoon sun, they would dry maize on the concrete pavilion of an abandoned nightclub called Super Star. The club itself was corn yellow, and fronted with smoked-glass windows, Corinthian columns, and sun-bleached posters showing attractive young Chinese revelers drinking expensive-looking cocktails and having the time of their lives.

在老挝亚热带的高温下，这里的浅色建筑开始剥落开裂。五年来，磨丁一直静静地坐落在丛林中，等待着新一轮的定居者带着下一个伟大的想法归来。

Its pastel buildings peeling and cracking in Laos’s subtropical heat, for five years Boten sat silently in the jungle, waiting for a new band of settlers to return with the next big idea.

*

*

2009 年 12 月 12 日，在老挝首都万象的一座崭新的体育场内，Phouthavong Outhasak 跪在教练面前，轻轻鞠躬，额头触地。这是第四天在第 25 届东南亚运动会开幕式上，这位当地武术选手刚刚在跆拳道决赛中击败了柬埔寨对手。看台上，当地观众欢呼雀跃，高喊“Lao, su, su！”（“老挝，战斗，战斗！”），这种无拘无束的欢呼声在这个说话温和的国家很少见。但今晚不同。老挝队首次主办运动会，有望赢得 33 枚金牌，打破 2007 年五枚金牌的纪录。向教练鞠躬后，Phouthavong 含着眼泪站起来，把老挝国旗系在脖子上，然后向观众欢呼，观众发出震撼的欢呼声。然后，他登上看台，走向的不是他的父亲，也不是他的母亲，而是老挝副总理 Somsavat Lengsavad。

In a brand new stadium in the Laotian capital of Vientiane on December 12, 2009, Phouthavong Outhasak knelt before his coach, gently bowed, and touched his forehead to the ground. It was day four of the twenty-fifth annual Southeast Asian Games, and the local martial arts fighter had just bested his Cambodian opponent in the taekwondo finals. In the stands, the local crowd was uproarious, chanting, “Lao, su, su!” (“Laos, fight, fight!”) in a display of unchecked exuberance rarely seen in this soft-spoken country. But tonight was different. Hosting the games for the first time, Team Laos was on track to win thirty-three gold medals, crushing its previous record of five in 2007. After bowing to his coach, Phouthavong rose with tears in his eyes and tied the Lao flag around his neck, then screamed in triumph at the crowd, which responded with a roar that shook the stands. He then scaled the grandstand and approached not his father, nor his mother, but Laos’s deputy prime minister, Somsavat Lengsavad.

这也是宋沙瓦的荣耀时刻。东南亚运动会是老挝的盛事，可能是该国有史以来举办的最精心策划的国家赛事。宋沙瓦曾领导组委会，现在他的努力得到了惊人的回报。每当播音员提到他的名字时，观众群就会欢呼雀跃。这位衣冠楚楚的政治家身着闪闪发光的白色夹克，在看台上笑容满面，主持了这场对一个不习惯赢得太多东西的国家来说意义重大的胜利。

It was a moment of glory for Somsavat, too. The Southeast Asian Games were a big deal for Laos, probably the most elaborate state event the country had ever held. Somsavat had led the organizing committee, and now his efforts were paying off spectacularly. Every time the announcers mentioned his name, the crowd of spectators cheered with approval. Draped in a shimmering white jacket, the dapper statesman beamed from the stands, presiding over what was turning out to be quite a triumph for a country not accustomed to winning much of anything.

这届运动会是老挝首次登上地区舞台，也是宋沙瓦的首秀。他正在打造令人羡慕的在人民革命党政治局中，他以能建好一切而闻名。奥运会的体育场是由一个中国公司财团通过 Somsavat 两年多前制定的秘密协议建造的。在会议上，中国国家开发银行的领导人提出建造这座耗资 1 亿美元的设施，但有一个条件：作为回报，老挝必须给中国一块附近的土地用于开发。两国同意在万象东北部一块面积为 4,000 英亩的泥泞土地上开发，这块土地被称为塔銮沼泽。

The Games were Laos’s debut on the regional stage, and they were also Somsavat’s. He was developing an enviable reputation in the Politburo of the People’s Revolutionary Party as a man who could get things built. The stadium for the Games was constructed by a consortium of Chinese companies through a backroom agreement devised over two years earlier by Somsavat. At the meeting, the leader of the China Development Bank offered to build the $100 million facility on one condition: In return, Laos would have to give China a separate plot of land nearby to develop. The two men agreed on a muddy 4,000-acre patch in northeast Vientiane called the That Luang marsh.

塔銮沼泽为老挝 17 个村庄提供了食物，村民们从咸水中捕捞蜗牛，从沼泽土壤中种植稻米。体育场交易完成后，政府将塔銮改名为“新城市开发项目”，但每个人都知道它的真实面目：一个强行塞进国家首都的唐人街。谣言四起，说那里很快就会出现一个中国的东西——也许是巨大的公寓大楼、廉价的商场，或者一个庞大的、与世隔绝的城市——而 Somsavat 的交易包括允许 50,000 名中国公民迁入开发区，这引起了老挝公众的罕见抗议。同样罕见的是 Somsavat 解释他在 2008 年 2 月的新闻发布会上坚称“不会歧视买家，也不会为中国公民提供特殊优惠”。 Somsavat 是华裔，曾在一所华小接受教育，但这并没有起到什么帮助作用。他淡化了自己的普通话流利程度，但这足以让他利用这一点与北京官员达成交易。

The That Luang marsh provided sustenance for seventeen Lao villages, whose residents harvested snails from its brackish waters and rice from its swampy soil. After the stadium deal, the government rebranded That Luang the “New City Development Project,” but everyone knew what it really was: a Chinatown shoehorned into the nation’s capital. Rumors swirled that soon, something would rise there, something Chinese—perhaps it would be monolithic condo towers, chintzy malls, or a hulking, insular city—and that Somsavat’s deal included a concession to allow 50,000 Chinese citizens to move into the development, which provoked a rare outcry from the Lao public. Equally rare was Somsavat’s impulse to explain himself. At a press conference in February 2008, he insisted there would be “no discrimination among buyers and no special concessions for Chinese citizens.” It did not help that Somsavat is ethnically Chinese and was educated in a Chinese primary school. He downplays his Mandarin fluency, but it’s serviceable enough that he can use it to cut deals with Beijing officials.

3 月，宋沙瓦举行了第二次新闻发布会，以遏制塔銮事件的影响，但抗议活动仍在继续，或许是因为沼泽地的部分区域归党员所有塔銮建筑群于 2010 年缩小了规模，如今，由上海万丰房地产公司建造的一排 19 层高的火烈鸟粉色公寓正在这片占地 900 英亩的土地上拔地而起。这些建筑环绕着一个人工湖，在潮湿的空气中闪闪发光，就像哨兵一样守护着那些照料沼泽剩余稻田的村民。这座建筑群在低层建筑的万象是一个异类，除了几条通道外，其余道路都与城市隔绝。据说，未来将规划高档零售店、娱乐中心和主题公园。

Somsavat held a second press conference in March to contain the That Luang fallout, but the protests continued, permitted, perhaps, because sections of the marsh were owned by Party members themselves. The That Luang complex was downsized in 2010, and today, a string of nineteen-story-tall flamingo-pink condominiums, built by the Shanghai Wan Feng Real Estate Company, are rising on the 900-acre site. The structures, encircling a manmade lake, shimmer in the humid air like sentinels watching over the villagers who tend to the marsh’s remaining rice paddies. The complex is an anomaly in low-rise Vientiane, cut off from the city by all but a few access roads. Upscale retail shops, an entertainment complex, and a theme park are said to be planned for the future.

体育场交易从头到尾都直接出自老挝的发展策略，即官员们以讨价还价的方式将本国的部分地区卖给外国建设项目。宋沙瓦是政治局最精明的玩家；可以肯定地说，没有其他老挝政客能在如此短的时间内为老挝带来如此多的外国发展。在这方面，他体现了当今东南亚许多人既渴望又害怕的东西：中国强势进入他们的国家，带着无法拒绝的昂贵礼物和提议，但中国日益增强的知名度也引发了人们对主权和身份的担忧。威斯康星大学麦迪逊分校的著名老挝问题专家伊恩·贝尔德说：“中国因其投资而具有重大影响力，但这种关系仍然爱恨交织。”对于较贫穷的对于寻求大规模基础设施的东南亚国家来说，中国往往是最佳选择。“如果你等着别人来建设这些基础设施，那永远都不可能，”塔斯马尼亚亚洲研究所的詹姆斯·钦说。“只有中国人才能快速完成。”

The stadium deal, from beginning to end, was straight out of the Laos development playbook, in which officials bargain away bits of the country in exchange for foreign-built projects. Somsavat was the Politburo’s savviest player of this game; it’s safe to say that no other Lao politician has brought more foreign development to Laos in such a short time. In this respect, he personifies what many in Southeast Asia today both yearn for and fear: the heavy hand of China reaching deep into their countries, bearing expensive gifts and offers one can’t refuse, but also a rising level of Chinese visibility that stirs up concerns about sovereignty and identity. “China has significant influence because of the investments they’ve made, but it’s still a love-hate relationship,” says Ian Baird, a leading Laos expert at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. For poorer Southeast Asian countries looking for large-scale infrastructure, China is often the best option. “If you wait for other people to come in and build this stuff, it will never happen,” says the Asia Institute Tasmania’s James Chin. “Only the Chinese can do it quickly.”

没有人比宋沙瓦·凌沙瓦更热衷于这一理论。自诩为老挝人的罗伯特·摩西怀有远大的梦想，而这个资金匮乏的国家却无法承受。他认为中国是修建高速公路、铁路和水电大坝的最快途径，他相信这些最终可以让老挝的命运与东南亚经济奇迹挂钩。史汀生中心的布莱恩·艾勒说：“老挝一直是一个争议地带。有些领导人更接近越南、泰国和中国。但在那些接近中国的人中，宋沙瓦一直是最接近中国的。”

No one subscribed to this theory more fervently than Somsavat Lengsavad. A self-fashioned Lao Robert Moses with dreams bigger than his cash-strapped nation could afford, he saw China as the quickest path to building the highways, railways, and hydroelectric dams he believed could finally tether Laos’s fortunes to the Southeast Asian economic miracle. “Laos has always been a zone of contention,” says the Stimson Center’s Brian Eyler. “There are leaders that are closer to Vietnam, to Thailand, to China. But of those that are close to China, Somsavat has always been the closest of them all.”

宋沙瓦出生并成长于老挝前首都琅勃拉邦，成长于 20 世纪 50 年代老挝的后殖民过渡时期。法国人没有留下多少东西。1953 年老挝王国政府掌权时，老挝只有不到 100 辆注册车辆，湄公河仍是其主要交通干道。又过了十年，电话服务才将省中心连接起来。对于许多老挝人来说，他们的生活仍与几个世纪前一样，靠从美国空运来的成袋的碾碎小麦补充生活。

Born and raised in the former Lao capital of Luang Prabang, Somsavat came of age in the 1950s during Laos’s postcolonial transition. The French hadn’t left much behind. When the Royal Lao Government took power in 1953, Laos had barely a hundred registered vehicles and the Mekong River was still its main transit artery. Another decade would pass before phone service would connect the provincial centers. For many Lao, life continued as it had for centuries, supplemented by airlifted sacks of bulgur from the United States.

新政府严重依赖美国的援助，许多老挝人对西方新势力的出现感到恐惧和不满，因为旧势力正准备撤离。越南共产党利用了这种怀疑态度，开始他们将自己的政治意识形态传播到边境。到 1955 年，老挝有了自己的共产党。在随后的几年里，老挝共产党游击队在越盟的支持下，与美国支持的老挝皇家军队在该国北部和东部发生了小规模冲突。随着老挝被卷入越南战争，这些游击队战士成长为一个有组织的这支共产主义叛乱力量被称为老挝爱国阵线，实际上由北越指挥。

The new government relied heavily on American aid, and many Lao feared and resented the visible presence of a new Western power just as the old one was departing. Vietnamese communists exploited this skepticism and began spreading their political ideology across the border. By 1955, Laos had its own communist party. In the years that followed, communist Lao guerrillas, backed by the Viet Minh, fought skirmishes with the American-supported Royal Lao Army in the country’s north and east. As Laos was pulled into the Vietnam War, these guerrilla fighters grew into an organized force, a communist insurgency known as the Pathet Lao that was effectively commanded by the North Vietnamese.

到 20 世纪 60 年代中期，巴特寮已控制了半个国家，并在这片领土内教育老挝青年，让他们了解外国势力和自由民主的危险。宋沙瓦就是其中一名青年。革命言论激发了他叛逆的青少年精神，他和一群同学辍学，为老挝的“独立”而战。到十几岁时，他已成为一名热情的革命者，在老挝共产党控制的北部洞穴中与政府军交火。他还是一名天生的领导者，组织村级和区级民兵，用民族主义故事来激怒农民，讲述外国人对老挝人民犯下的不公正行为。19 岁时，他被任命为革命运动指挥官凯山·丰威汉的秘书。凯山于 1975 年夺取政权后，宋沙瓦开始为老挝新任总理工作。

By the mid 1960s the Pathet Lao controlled access to half the country, and within this territory, it educated Lao youth on the dangers of foreign influence and liberal democracy. Somsavat was one of these youths. The revolutionary talk appealed to his rebellious teenage spirit, and with a group of his classmates he dropped out of school to fight for Laos’s “independence.” By his mid-teens he had become an enthusiastic revolutionary, trading fire with government forces in the caves of the country’s communist-controlled north. He was also an instinctual leader, organizing village- and district-level militias, and regaling the peasantry with nationalistic tales of the injustices that foreigners had perpetrated upon the Lao people. At nineteen, he was appointed secretary to Kaysone Phomvihane, the revolutionary movement’s commander. When Kaysone seized power in 1975, Somsavat found himself working for the new prime minister of Laos.

刚上台后，这个羽翼未丰的共产主义政权开始将国家划分为农业集体，因为它认为这样生产力更高，也更容易受到中央集权控制。然而，从一开始，这些集体就失败了，到 1979 年，政府已经允许某些形式的资本主义企业稳定经济。这些改革发生的时候，邓小平也在对中国的经济进行自由化，尽管中越紧张局势阻碍了老挝与中国建立密切关系，但邓小平的改革肯定影响了老挝。1989 年，凯松访问了北京——这是天安门广场屠杀事件后第一位访问北京的国家元首。这次访问似乎表明，在苏联摇摇欲坠之际，老挝希望加强与共产主义邻国的关系。

Once in office, the fledgling communist regime set about slicing the country into agricultural collectives, which it believed would be more productive and more susceptible to centralized control. From the start, however, the collectives were a failure, and by 1979 the government was already permitting certain forms of capitalistic enterprise to stabilize the economy. These reforms occurred just as Deng Xiaoping was liberalizing China’s economy as well, and though Sino-Vietnamese tensions prevented Laos from enjoying intimate ties with China, Deng’s reforms surely influenced Laos’s. In 1989, Kaysone visited Beijing—the first head of state to do so after the Tienanmen Square massacre. The visit seemed to signal Laos’s desire to shore up ties to its communist neighbors as the Soviet Union teetered.

与此同时，宋沙瓦开始步步高升，于 1998 年成为副总理。他的名字很快就成为老挝日益增多的外国基础设施的代名词。他通过谈判在湄公河上修建水电站，推动老挝成为“东南亚电池”的长期目标，这一经济战略非常适合这个被强大的越南一分为二的内陆国家。老挝的目标是到 2020 年使水力发电能力达到 12,000 兆瓦，到 2030 年再翻一番，并出口 80% 的能源。

Meanwhile, Somsavat began his ascent, becoming deputy prime minister in 1998. His name soon became synonymous with Laos’s proliferating foreign-built infrastructure. He negotiated deals to put hydropower dams on the Mekong, advancing Laos’s long-term goal of becoming the “battery of Southeast Asia,” an economic strategy befitting a landlocked country bisected by a powerful river. Laos’s goal was to get its hydropower generation capacity up to 12,000 megawatts by 2020, then double that by 2030, and export 80 percent of the energy.

索姆萨瓦也是这位面色严肃的政治局委员最接近人性化的使者，他经常被派去在公共活动中微笑，对国家控制的新闻界喋喋不休。但他在公众面前表现出的和蔼可亲的外表下隐藏着一个好斗、身经百战的斗士。他曾经在五十人面前斥责他的翻译，因为他敢于坐着，而他站着。那些屈尊提出偏离慢速提问方式的记者会遭到他的怒火；他曾在新闻发布会结束时对媒体大喊：“如果我不是最好的，我就不是老板！”2009 年，在一次组织在东南亚运动会的会议上，他猛烈抨击国家体育委员会主席，质问他：“委员会有没有给拳击手找出气筒？如果没有，他们可以用主席来出气。”

Somsavat was also the closest thing the grim-faced Politburo had to a humanizing emissary, and was often dispatched to grin at public events and jabber at the state-controlled press corps. But the genial front he presented to the public masked a belligerent, battle-hardened brawler. He once upbraided his interpreter in front of fifty people for daring to sit while he was standing. Journalists who deigned to ask questions that strayed from the slow-pitch formula faced his wrath; he once wrapped up a press conference by shouting at the media, “If I wasn’t the best, I would not be the boss!” In 2009, at an organizing meeting for the Southeast Asian Games, he lashed out at the head of the National Sports Committee, asking, “Has the committee brought a punching bag for the boxers? If not, they can use the chairman instead.”

在一个让别人丢脸是极大罪孽的社会里，宋沙瓦的咄咄逼人的性格令人震惊。这种性格在产生结果方面也非常有效。在为发展扫清道路的过程中，他逆着历史的逆风前进，几百年来，历史的逆风让老挝基本上与东南亚的经济攀升保持距离。在1300 年代，老挝是一个被称为澜沧的岛国，未能征收足以资助公共工程项目和城市建设计划的税款。它错过了欧洲航海商人给沿海邻国带来的经济发展。当法国殖民该国时，它被忽视了，老挝进一步陷入停滞。

In a society where causing others to lose face is a paramount sin, Somsavat’s aggressive nature was jarring. It was also remarkably effective at producing results. In clearing the way for development, he was pushing against the headwinds of history, which for centuries have largely held Laos at arm’s length from Southeast Asia’s economic climb. In the 1300s, Laos was an insular kingdom known as Lan Xang that failed to collect the taxes that could have funded public works projects and city-building initiatives. It missed out on the economic evolutions brought to its coastal neighbors by seafaring European traders. When the French colonized the country, it left it neglected, and Laos further stagnated.

如今，老挝的政治局神秘而偏执，是该国非政府组织数量稀少的原因，该国的英文报纸 《万象时报》是一份纯粹的宣传大报。外国记者经常以游客身份进入老挝，低调工作。公开异议很少见，那些选择发声的人冒着遭到可怕报复的风险。2012 年，该国最著名的人权活动家 Sombath Somphone 在一个警察检查站失踪。他失踪的潜台词很明显：不要将经济开放与言论自由混为一谈。

Today, Laos’s cryptic and paranoid Politburo is the reason the country has few NGOs, and its English-language newspaper, The Vientiane Times, is a broadsheet of pure propaganda. Foreign journalists in Laos often enter as tourists and work under the radar. Public dissent is rare, and those who choose to speak up risk fearsome retribution. In 2012, the country’s best-known human rights activist, Sombath Somphone, vanished at a police checkpoint. The subtext of his disappearance was clear: Don’t confuse economic openness with the freedom to speak your mind.

该国的历史惰性部分归因于其缺乏连通基础设施。它没有港口也没有与其他东南亚国家相媲美的高速公路。为了解决这个问题，在宋沙瓦等领导人的领导下，老挝日益向全球市场靠拢，并将“发展”作为人民革命党的试金石。

The country’s historical inertia has been due, in part, to its hobbling lack of connective infrastructure. It has no ports and no freeways comparable to other Southeast Asian nations. To remedy this, under leaders like Somsavat, Laos has increasingly courted the global market and made “development” the defining touchstone of the People’s Revolutionary Party.

老挝实际上没有铁路。它唯一的火车服务是一辆玩具般的火车头，以老挝特有的速度在两英里长的轨道上行驶。它本质上只是泰国铁路网的一个支线，是泰国铁路网的摇摇欲坠的延伸，在老挝边境，在距离万象十二英里的一片尘土飞扬的田野中突然终止。即使是小小的吉布提、卢森堡、斐济、瑙鲁和圣基茨和尼维斯也拥有更多的铁路。

Laos is a country that, practically speaking, has no railway. Its lone train service is a toylike locomotive that plies a two-mile track at a distinctly Lao-like pace. It is essentially just a stub, a rickety extension of the Thai rail network that, on the Laos side of the border, ends abruptly in a dusty field a dozen miles short of Vientiane. Even tiny Djibouti, Luxembourg, Fiji, Nauru, and St. Kitts and Nevis have more railways.

距离上一次有人试图在老挝修建一条真正的铁路，已经过去了近一个世纪。20 世纪 20 年代，法国开始规划一条连接老挝和越南广平省的铁路。其目标是鼓励越南人移民到老挝西部人口稀少的殖民地。但大萧条迫使法国取消了该项目，该项目也从此再也没有恢复。

It’s been nearly a century since anyone attempted to build a proper railway in Laos. In the 1920s, France began planning one that would have connected the country to Vietnam’s Quang Binh province. The goal was to encourage Vietnamese migration into its sparsely populated colony to the west. But the Great Depression forced France to cancel the project, and it was never revived.

21 世纪初，中国开始规划自己的老挝铁路，这次是连接昆明和万象，目标是获取老挝的自然资源，并将云南省与泰国边境连接起来。2009 年，中国和老挝同意继续推进该项目，并于 2010 年 4 月 7 日签署了一份谅解备忘录，启动昆明-万象铁路的建设。

In the early 2000s, when China began plotting its own Lao railway, this time linking Kunming with Vientiane, the goal was to access Laos’s natural resources and connect Yunnan Province to the Thai border. In 2009, China and Laos agreed to pursue the project, and on April 7, 2010, signed a memorandum of understanding setting the Kunming-Vientiane Railway in motion.

该项目从一开始就遭遇挫折。签署不到一年后，代表北京签署谅解备忘录的中国铁道部长刘志军因腐败。“坦率地说，部长改组“项目进度放缓，”Somsavat 表示，同时他也承认，一系列社会和环境影响研究“没有达到我们的预期”。几个月后，中国温州郊区发生一起高铁相撞事故，造成 40 人死亡，引发了人们对中国铁路安全性的质疑。

The project suffered setbacks from the get-go. Less than a year after the signing, Liu Zhijun, the Chinese minister of railways who had executed the MoU on behalf of Beijing, was fired for corruption. “Frankly speaking, the ministerial reshuffle has slowed down the project,” Somsavat said, while also admitting that a series of social and environmental impact studies “didn’t meet our expectations.” A few months later, a high-speed train collision in the Chinese suburb of Wenzhou killed forty people, raising doubts about the safety of China’s railways.

宋沙瓦没有气馁。在与中国成功合作兴建体育场馆后，他继续支持铁路建设，并于 2012 年召集老挝国会特别会议批准该计划。他甚至在老挝审查制度之外的媒体上大谈该项目。他告诉日本《 日经亚洲评论》：“这将促进老挝经济发展，因为许多投资者现在都想在这里建立生产基地。他们说，如果老挝有铁路，将有助于他们降低运输成本。因此，这将使我们对投资者更具吸引力。”

Somsavat was undeterred. Fresh off his successful stadium collaboration with China, he continued to champion the railway, and in 2012 convened a special session of Laos’s National Assembly to rubber-stamp the scheme. He even talked up the project with media outlets outside Laos’s censorship bubble. “It will boost the Lao economy because many investors are now looking for a production base here,” he told Japan’s Nikkei Asian Review. “They say that if the country had a railway, it would help them reduce their transportation costs. So it would make us more attractive to investors.”

然而，并非所有人都能从中受益。一位老挝官员告诉自由亚洲电台，这条铁路将占用近 10,000 英亩土地，将导致 4,400 多户老挝家庭流离失所。老挝公共工程和交通部副部长表示，中央政府正在与省级工作组合作，对流离失所的居民进行补偿，但一些已经放弃家园为该项目让路的人几个月后仍未得到补偿，他们怀疑自己是否能得到房产全额补偿。

Not everyone would benefit, however. The railway would require nearly 10,000 acres of land, displacing over 4,400 Lao families, a Lao official told Radio Free Asia. Laos’s deputy minister of public works and transport said the central government was working with provincial task forces to compensate the uprooted residents, but some who had already given up their homes to make way for the project still hadn’t been compensated months later, and were skeptical they’d ever be reimbursed for the full value of their properties.

一条定制铁路将实现老挝从“陆锁国”变为“陆联国”的梦想，老挝官员在推广该计划时不断提到这句话。这笔交易确立了合资公司为该项目提供资金。中国持有该公司 70% 的股份，老挝持有剩余的 30%。铁路总预算约为 60 亿美元，低于最初估计的 70 亿美元，分析师们已经认为这个数字非常乐观。在这 60 亿美元中，初始投资将略高于 20 亿美元，其中中国将出资约 16 亿美元。老挝将承担其余部分。

A made-to-order railway would fulfill Laos’s dream of going from landlocked to “land-linked,” a phrase uttered endlessly by Lao officials promoting the scheme. The deal established a joint venture company to finance the project. China holds 70 percent of this company, and Laos holds the remaining 30 percent. The total budget for the railway is about $6 billion, pared down from an original estimate of $7 billion, a figure analysts had already considered to be extremely optimistic. Of this $6 billion, the initial investment will be just over $2 billion, of which China will contribute about $1.6 billion. Laos will cover the rest.

然而，老挝根本没有那么多现金，因此它将从中国借款来承担大部分费用。老中铁路公司网站于 2017 年 5 月表示，这笔贷款的利率为 2.3%，但知情人士此前估计利率接近 3%。然而，即使按 2.3% 的利率计算，该项目 60 亿美元的总成本也将相当于老挝整个 GDP 的近一半，并可能使该国陷入无法摆脱的债务困境，并使未来获得更紧迫需求的融资变得困难。

Laos, however, has nowhere near that kind of cash lying around, so it will borrow most of its share of the cost from China. A website for the Lao-China Railway Company stated in May 2017 that the interest rate for this loan would be 2.3 percent, though people with knowledge of the deal previously pegged it at closer to 3 percent. Even at the 2.3 percent rate, however, the total $6 billion cost of the project would equal nearly half of Laos’s entire GDP, and could hobble the country with inescapable debt and complicate access to future financing for more pressing needs.

这条负债累累的铁路与老挝的性格格格不入，因为老挝官僚以大萧条时代的心态管理国家。老挝对债务的恐惧是可以理解的。2015 年的某个时候，政府的外汇储备还不到两个月，而且偶尔政府一直无法按时支付公务员的工资。即使是老挝的银行也不愿意接受现金。当我试图在万象最大的银行提取 600 美元时，经理先是劝阻我，然后同意给我一半。

The debt-heavy railway is oddly out of character, since Laotian bureaucrats run the country with a Depression-era mentality. Laos’s fear of debt is understandable. At one point in 2015, the government had less than two months of foreign currency reserves, and has occasionally been unable to pay its civil servants on time. Even banks in Laos are wary of parting with cash. When I tried to withdraw 600 U.S. dollars at the biggest bank in Vientiane, the manager first tried to talk me out of it, then agreed to give me half.

相反，老挝的开发往往通过“建设-运营-转让”的安排进行，即外国实体在老挝建设基础设施，然后在一定年限内获得利润。在商定的期限后，基础设施将移交给老挝政府。此类安排为在湄公河及其支流上建造多座水坝提供了资金。

Instead, development in Laos is often done through “build-operate-transfer” arrangements, in which a foreign entity builds infrastructure in Laos, then reaps its profits for a set number of years. After an agreed upon timeframe, the infrastructure is then handed over to the Lao government. Such arrangements have financed the building of multiple dams on the Mekong River and its tributaries.

老挝愿意承担如此巨额债务来修建铁路，最合理的解释是，老挝迫切需要基础设施，宋沙瓦的个人野心，以及这笔交易背后的交易——支持老挝工业发展综合体许多重大项目的幕后交易。一位老挝政治专家说：“老挝的一些领导人是靠中国金钱外交上位和留任的。老挝政府的一些副部长是中国支付了两三百万美元。中国还为他们提供薪水。你们有这种程度的参与，这滋养和维持了这些联盟。”

Laos’s willingness to take on such a large amount of debt to build the railway is most plausibly explained by its desperate need for infrastructure, by Somsavat’s personal ambition, and by the deals behind the deal—the palm-greased scaffolding that supports many of the major projects of Laos’s industrial development complex. “There are leaders in Laos who were put in place and are held there by China’s checkbook diplomacy,” says one expert on Lao politics. “You have vice ministers in the Lao government for whom China has paid two or three million dollars. China bankrolls their salaries, too. You have that level of involvement, and it feeds and sustains these alliances.”

一位外国外交官表示，中国通过定期拜访来补充这些回扣，“不仅奉承老挝官员，中国和老挝代表在这些会议上交换了具体的东西。”老挝政治保密和自由经济相结合，使其容易滋生腐败。在一个由少数有权势的人控制的不透明体系中，赢得西方领导人赞誉的市场经济类型也为裙带资本主义铺平了道路。据欧盟支持的 GAN 商业反腐败组织称据门户网站报道，自2000年以来，老挝已有超过900万英亩土地转让给私营公司，其中大部分交易“是由于土地管理部门和政客之间的腐败而实现的”。

China supplements these kickbacks with regular drop-ins that “don’t just flatter Lao officials—concrete things get exchanged between Chinese and Lao delegates at these meetings,” according to a foreign diplomat. Laos’s mix of political secrecy and liberal economics makes it prone to corruption. In an opaque system controlled by a powerful few, the type of market economy that earns kudos from Western leaders also paves the way for crony capitalism. According to the EU-backed GAN Business Anti-Corruption Portal, over nine million acres of Laotian land have been transferred to private companies since 2000, much of it in deals “made possible by corruption in the land administration and among politicians.”

腐败现象已经非常严重，政府自己的国家检查局发布了一份报告2012 年至 2014 年间，揭露腐败让老挝损失了 1.2 亿美元，其中数百万美元被各部委和省级办公室挪用。为了应对腐败，老挝政府开展了北京式的反腐运动，调查官员贪污情况，并公开拍卖党内官员的奔驰和宝马，而这些官员现在开的都是丰田凯美瑞。

The rot runs deep enough that the government’s own State Inspection Authority released a report showing corruption had cost Laos $120 million between 2012 and 2014, with millions of it embezzled by ministries and provincial-level offices. In response, the regime embarked on a Beijing-style anti-corruption drive, investigating bureaucrats for graft and publicly auctioning off the Mercedes and BMWs owned by party apparatchiks, who now drive Toyota Camrys instead.

透明国际在 2016 年奖励了清理运动将老挝列为世界第 51 个最腐败国家。（十年前，它位列前 10 名。）然而，由于 7% 的增长率和言论自由禁令，不正当行为继续猖獗，随之而来的是价值存疑的发展项目。

Transparency International rewarded the cleanup campaign in 2016 by ranking Laos the world’s fifty-first most corrupt state. (A decade earlier it was in the top 10.) And yet, thanks to a placating growth rate of 7 percent and a ban on free speech, impropriety continues to flourish, and with it, development projects of questionable worth.

“我们都知道政府有多腐败，但我们只在车里和公寓里谈论它，”万象一位健谈的出租车司机罕见地在椅子上发表政治评论。“老挝人就像老鼠一样，大家都同意要给当地的猫戴铃铛。但要让这个计划奏效，就得有一只老鼠把铃铛挂在猫脖子上，但在老挝，没有人会自愿这么做。”

“All of us know how corrupt the government is, but we only talk about it in our cars and our flats,” a chatty Vientiane taxi driver told me in a rare display of armchair political commentary. “Lao people are like mice who all agree they need to put a bell on the local cat. But for the plan to work, one mouse has to put the bell around the cat’s neck, and in Laos, no one will volunteer.”

2015 年 12 月是老挝人民民主共和国一党执政四十周年，为庆祝这一成就，人民革命党安排了三项大型活动。首先，它在首都街头举行了 48 场“鼓舞人心的游行”，据《 万象时报》 报道，“老挝人民全民心都为民族自豪感而跳动。”其次，它启动了老挝第一个老挝一号卫星是一颗电信轨道卫星，旨在改善该国人口稀少地区的连通性。

December 2015 marked forty years of one-party rule in the Lao PDR, and to celebrate its streak, the People’s Revolutionary Party scheduled three big events. First, it flooded the capital’s streets with forty-eight “inspiring parades,” during which, as the Vientiane Times reported, “all Lao hearts were beating with national pride.” Second, it launched Laos’s first satellite, LaoSat-1, a telecommunications orbital designed to improve connectivity across the country’s sparsely populated landscape.

第三，这里举行了铁路奠基仪式。老挝与中国签署协议已经五年了。当这个重要的日子终于到来时，两国领导人站在一排由中国重型机械公司柳工制造的挖土机前，用铲子将沙土推入脚踝高的沙堆中。在一个有顶棚的展台上，代表们对模型火车和精美的效果图窃笑不已。

And third, it held a groundbreaking for the railway. Five years had elapsed since Laos had signed the agreement with China. When the big day finally arrived, leaders from both countries stood before a row of earth-movers built by LiuGong, the Chinese heavy-machinery company, and pushed shovels into ankle-high pyramids of sand. At a canopied booth, delegates tittered over model trains and glossy renderings.

《万象时报》报道称， 借助这些活动，“老挝向世界宣扬其成功”。但这场盛会也凸显了执政政权的尴尬现实。卫星和铁路其实更多的是中国的成就，而不是老挝的成就。中国出资建造了耗资 2.59 亿美元的 LaoSat-1，从四川省发射，并在其绕地球运行期间拥有 55% 的股份。至于铁路，尽管人们都说它是中老合资企业，但它一直更符合中国的需求。对于中国这样一个旅游人数不断膨胀的出口导向型国家来说，修建一条铁路将货物和人员运往南方似乎是明智之举。但老挝的出口并不多，而且它所出口的那点点货物主要来自沙湾拿吉省，丰田和尼康等公司在那里设有制造基地，而铁路不会在那里通行。

With these events, the Vientiane Times reported, “Laos trumpeted its success to the world.” But the extravaganza also threw into relief an uncomfortable reality for the ruling regime. The satellite and the railway were really more China’s achievements than Laos’s. China financed and built LaoSat-1 to the tune of $259 million, launched it from Sichuan Province, and owns 55 percent of it even as it orbits Earth. As for the railway, for all the talk of it being a Sino-Lao joint venture, it’s always been more geared toward China’s needs. For China, an export-oriented country with a ballooning tourist class, a railway to ship goods and people southward seems to make sense. But Laos doesn’t export much, and what little it does mainly comes out of Savannakhet Province, where companies like Toyota and Nikon have manufacturing bases—and where the railway won’t run.

在四十周年之际，政治局委员们自问，他们希望中国在多大程度上参与他们的事务。动工七周后，他们在政府第十次会议上回答了这个问题党代会。在老挝国家会议中心举行的国旗飘扬的游行队伍中，代表 20 多万党员的 685 名代表对政治局进行了改组。改组结束后，三名代表最热衷于亲华派的成员被罢免：总理、总书记和宋沙瓦·凌沙瓦。被提拔为总书记的是 78 岁的党内骨干本扬·沃拉吉，他被认为更倾向于越南，他年轻时曾在越南接受过军事训练。

At the time of the fortieth anniversary, members of the Politburo were asking themselves how much they want China involved in their matters. Seven weeks after the groundbreaking, they answered this question at the government’s tenth party congress. Staged at the Lao National Convention Center amid flag-festooned parades, 685 delegates representing over 200,000 party members reshuffled the Politburo. When they were finished, the three members representing its most fervently pro-Chinese wing were out: the prime minister, the general secretary, and Somsavat Lengsavad. Elevated to general secretary was a seventy-eight-year-old party stalwart named Bounnhang Vorachit, who was seen as more oriented toward Vietnam, where he received his military training as a youth.

此次大改组传递的信息很明确。中共认为，中国已经走得太近了，而中国支持者，包括宋沙瓦，必须下台。尽管中老两国距离很近，而且都有着共同的共产主义传统，但两国的历史却很复杂。上世纪 80 年代，北京支持老挝的叛乱，在中国训练战士，然后派他们带着 AK-47 步枪回国与老挝政府作战。老挝与泰国在文化、宗教和语言方面有更多共同之处。从历史上看，老挝最亲密的盟友一直是越南，即巴特寮党的发源地。在凯山时代，越南和老挝的关系非常密切，以至于一些老挝领导人既自称是老挝人，又自称是越南人，根据当时的情况在两种身份之间来回转换。

The shakeup’s message was clear. China had gotten too close, the party had decided, and China’s enablers, Somsavat chief among them, had to go. Despite their proximity and shared communist heritage, China and Laos have a checkered history. In the 1980s, Beijing supported an insurgency in Laos, training combatants in China and sending them back with AK-47s to fight the Lao government. Laos shares far more with Thailand in terms of culture, religion, and language. And historically, its most intimate ally has long been Vietnam, the birthplace of the Pathet Lao. Back in the Kaysone days, Vietnam and Laos were so enmeshed that some Lao leaders identified as both Lao and Vietnamese, toggling between personas to suit the situation at hand.

老挝不会在做出重大决定之前先考虑河内对此的看法。越南是老挝最大的外国投资者，与中国竞争，而且越南也是对中国的强烈怀疑者。连接老挝和云南省的大型铁路只会削弱越南的影响力。政治局的清洗有助于让越南确信老挝仍然是它的同道中人。

Laos doesn’t make a big decision without first considering how Hanoi might feel about it. Vietnam rivals China as Laos’s biggest foreign investor, and it is a fierce China skeptic, as well. A massive railway tying Laos to Yunnan Province could only diminish Vietnamese influence. The Politburo purge helped reassure Vietnam that Laos was still its kindred spirit.

为了建设铁路，宋沙瓦愿意将政治放在一边，这反映出一种非常中国化的思维方式。但最终，老挝还没有准备好接受这种后政治思维。对于宋沙瓦来说，这种转变一定令人震惊。四十年前，在距离会议中心不远的一所高中体育馆里，他曾与胜利的巴特寮叛军一起为现在已被他赶下台的共产党政府起草计划。国家控制的媒体对他的退出进行了极其优雅的描述——官方说法是，他只是“不竞选连任”——这表明该党对铁路的热情仍然非常高涨。宋沙瓦甚至还间接参与了铁路的实施，充当与中国之间的非官方中间人，就像一位退休的美国政客从事说客工作一样。

Somsavat’s willingness to put aside politics in the interest of getting something built reflects a very Chinese way of thinking. But in the end, Laos wasn’t ready for this kind of post-political mindset. For Somsavat, the turnabout must have been jarring. Forty years earlier, not far from the convention center, he had stood in a high school gymnasium with victorious Pathet Lao rebels, drawing up plans for the communist government that had now ejected him. His exit was depicted with the utmost grace by the state-controlled press—officially, he simply “didn’t stand for re-election”—suggesting that the party’s enthusiasm for the railway remains very much alive. Somsavat is even still tangentially involved in its execution, acting as an unofficial go-between with China, like a retired American politician taking a job as a lobbyist.

然而，此时此刻，索姆萨瓦可能不再是该项目成功的关键。事实上，自从他离开以来，实地工作已经明显加快。在他卸任三个月后，即 4 月 23 日，2016 年，中国外交部长王毅抵达老挝，急切地希望讨论铁路的进展情况。但当时进展不大，王毅在那里表达了自己的失望。他与老挝琅勃拉邦省省长坎坎·占达维苏的谈话既亲切又紧张。王毅提醒省长：“中老是命运共同体。两国是战略伙伴，两国人民是兄弟姐妹。”因此，王毅在谈到尚未修建的铁路时说：“中国已经实现了这些年中国取得了一些发展，作为好邻居，希望老挝也能更快发展。”

At this point, however, Somsavat may no longer be key to the project’s success. Since his departure, in fact, work on the ground has accelerated noticeably. Three months after he stepped down, on April 23, 2016, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi arrived in Laos eager to discuss progress on the railway. At that point, there hadn’t been much, and Wang Yi was there to express his disappointment. His conversation with Khamkhanh Chamthavisouk, the Governor of Laos’s Luang Prabang province, was cordial but tense. Wang Yi reminded the governor that “China and Laos are a community of common destiny. The two countries are strategic partners and the two peoples are brothers and sisters.” For that reason, Wang Yi said in regard to the still-unbuilt railway, “China has achieved some development in these years, and as a good neighbor, it hopes that Laos will also develop more quickly.”

如此冷酷的鼓励之声一直从北京传来，直到 2016 年圣诞节，万象举行了第二次奠基仪式，距第一次奠基仪式已过去了近一年。老挝新任总理通伦·西苏里站在一旁，老挝公共工程和交通部部长向人群发表讲话。宋沙瓦则静静地站在一旁。部长说：“一旦建成，这条铁路将造福老挝各族人民。”一位中国代表走上讲台，向所有人保证，自第一次奠基以来，工程建设一直在快速推进。

Such icy beads of encouragement continued to drip from Beijing until, on Christmas Day of 2016, Vientiane held a second groundbreaking, nearly a year after the first. The country’s new prime minister, Thongloun Sisoulith, stood by as Laos’s Minister of Public Works and Transport addressed the crowd. Somsavat stood quietly off to the side. “Once completed, the railway will benefit Lao people of all ethnic groups,” said the minister. A Chinese delegate took to the podium to reassure everyone that in the time since the first groundbreaking, engineering had continued apace.

看来这些都没错。到 2017 年夏天，中国工人已经在万象以北小城万荣周围的山丘上挖隧道。琅勃拉邦周围，工人们正在清理土地。据报道，在老挝与中国边界以南的乌多姆塞省，正在修建别墅，供中国工人居住。突然间，一反常态地，人们感觉到老挝即将发生大事。

That much appears to be true. By the summer of 2017, Chinese workers were tunneling through the hills around Vang Vieng, a small city north of Vientiane. Around Luang Prabang, workers are clearing the land. In Oudomxay Province, just south of the Lao-Chinese border, villas are reportedly being constructed to house Chinese workers. Suddenly, uncharacteristically, there is a sense that something big is coming to Laos.

为了一睹它的风采，2017 年 3 月，我从曼谷乘坐夜班火车，来到万象附近那片尘土飞扬的田野，乘坐的是中国制造的豪华新头等卧铺车厢。这是泰国国家铁路公司 20 年来购买的第一辆新车。我的手机在床边的 USB 端口上充电，脚边的触摸屏电视闪闪发光。到达老挝首都后，我雇了一名司机，继续向北前往磨丁市，花了两天时间，爬了 400 英里翻越无尽的山路。我想看看人烟稀少的中老边境地区到底发生了什么，这条百年来一直是帝国幻想的铁路终于在这里开工了。

To get a glimpse, in March 2017 I took an overnight train from Bangkok to that dusty field near Vientiane, riding in a luxurious new first-class Chinese-built sleeper car. It was the first new rolling stock that State Railways of Thailand had purchased in twenty years. My phone charged in a bedside USB port while a touch-screen TV glowed just beyond my feet. When I reached the Lao capital, I hired a driver and continued north to the city of Boten, a two-day, 400-mile climb over endless mountain switchbacks. I wanted to see what was going on in the thinly settled China-Laos border region, where work had finally begun on a railway that had been an imperial fantasy for a hundred years.

最具国际化现代化的城市

A Most Internationally Modernized City

乌多姆赛位于中国边境以南约 60 英里处，是老挝北部重工业的集散地，也是区域货物运输的枢纽。20 年前，这里还是一个高地村庄，但随着中国企业家的定居，这里的人口已激增至约 25,000 人。现在，这里到处都是卖蒸汽铲的汽车经销店和兜售金属板的街头小贩。在一家商店里，我看到一位老人抽着一根被改造成水烟筒的 PVC 管。盛昌酒店是一座六层楼的宫殿，以紫色和金色装饰，是乌多姆赛唯一的魅力所在，但酒店里空无一人，楼上昏暗的楼层只有大厅里闪着蓝色光芒的门铃，就像跑道灯一样。酒店唯一看似是工作人员的是一位老挝接待员，她说，他们接待的客人很少，都是中国项目经理，但他们预计不久就会订满：乌多姆赛很快就会有火车站。

Some sixty miles south of the Chinese border lies Oudomxay, a gritty staging site in northern Laos for heavy industry and a transport hub for regional cargo flows. Twenty years ago this was a highland village, but its population has ballooned to about 25,000 as Chinese entrepreneurs have settled in. Now it’s filled with auto dealerships selling steam shovels and street vendors hawking sheet metal. In one shop, I watched an elderly man puff on a PVC pipe that had been turned into a bong. The Sheng Chang Hotel, a six-story palace of purple and gold that’s the only glamour to be found in Oudomxay, is largely empty, and the darkened floors above are lit only by glowing blue doorbells that line the halls like runway lights. The hotel’s only apparent staff, a Lao receptionist, says the few guests they receive are Chinese project managers, but that they expect to be fully booked before long: Oudomxay will soon have a railway station.

圣昌坐落在南高河的一侧，这条河沿着城镇的西部边缘流淌，滋养着一片延伸到地平线的稻田。其中一片稻田属于 Somphone Phomexay，他是一位说话温和的水电工程师，20 世纪 90 年代他从万象被派往乌多姆赛，帮助修建附近的南高河大坝。从那时起，他就一直在大坝工作，同时收割稻米和果树以补充收入。

The Sheng Chang sits on one side of the Nam Ko River, which runs along the western edge of town and nourishes a collection of rice paddies that stretches toward the horizon. One of these paddies belongs to Somphone Phomexay, a soft-spoken hydroelectric engineer who was sent to Oudomxay from Vientiane in the 1990s to help build the nearby Nam Ko River Dam. He’s worked at the dam ever since, while harvesting rice and fruit trees to supplement his income.

2016 年夏末的一天，Somphone 的村长请他和七个邻居去见一位面无表情的政府官员。“村长解释说，我们的田地将被收回，作为火车站的所在地，”Somphone 说。“然后官员帮我填写了一份补偿申请表。”Somphone 尽职尽责地填好表格并递交给村长。不久之后，一队中国测量员穿过他的稻田，测量土地。

One day in the late summer of 2016, Somphone’s village chief asked him and seven of his neighbors to come to a meeting with a poker-faced government official. “The chief explained that our fields would be reclaimed as the site of the railway station,” says Somphone. “Then the official helped me fill out an application for compensation.” Somphone dutifully filled out the paperwork and handed it over. Shortly thereafter, a team of Chinese surveyors were trundling through his rice paddy, measuring the land.

Somphone 的田地是该省罕见的平地，周围是崎岖的山脉和雾气弥漫的山谷。这是地球上最崎岖的地形之一，铁路将直接穿过它。立面图线路的运行速度与心脏病患者的心率相似，在老挝北部蜿蜒曲折，然后在南部平原平稳运行。该线路将需要 150 多座桥梁和 70 条隧道。其中七条隧道长度超过四英里。山脉是不稳定的石灰岩，铁路将穿过的地区到处都是美国在越南战争期间在老挝投下的 2.7 亿枚炸弹留下的未爆炸弹药。这足以让人怀疑这条铁路是否会建成。

Somphone’s field is part of a rare spit of level land in a province besieged by craggy mountains and misty valleys. It’s some of the most rugged terrain on earth, and the railway will run straight through it. An elevation diagram of the route resembles a cardiac patient’s heart rate, zigzagging up and down through Northern Laos before flatlining along the plains in the south. The route will require over 150 bridges and 70 tunnels. Seven of these tunnels will be more than four miles long. The mountains are unstable limestone and the area the railway will run through is littered with unexploded ordinance left over from the 270 million bombs dropped on Laos by the U.S. during the Vietnam War. It’s enough to cast doubt on whether it will ever be built.

然而，一些迹象已经显现。从边境到乌多姆赛，路边大片新平整的土地上，挖土机静静地开动。身穿蓝白相间制服的中国工人蹲在路边铝板覆盖的宿舍旁抽烟，宿舍正面挂着宝蓝色横幅，用老挝语和普通话宣传该项目： 中铁五局磨丁-万象铁路段建设管理部。一号混凝土搅拌站欢迎您。修建老中铁路。造福老中两国人民。

And yet, signs of something coming are apparent. Earth-movers sit atop tracts of freshly leveled land all along the roadside from the border to Oudomxay. Chinese workers in blue and white uniforms squat and smoke by aluminum-clad roadside dormitories, their facades sporting royal blue banners marketing the project in Lao and Mandarin: China Railway Number 5 Engineering Group, Boten-Vientiane Railway Section, Department of Construction Management. Number 1 Concrete Mixing Plant Welcomes You. Building the Laos-China Railway. Bringing Benefits to the Lao and Chinese People.

住在这些宿舍里的一些工人可能会在路边不远处的新水泥厂工作，就在 Nam Veun 村外。蓝白相间的筒仓高耸于庆祝工厂落成的广告牌上，你可以在乌多姆赛下游找到类似的筒仓，能源公司中国电力正在那里建造一座大型水电站。这是中国在湄公河上游修建的一系列水坝中最新的一座。自 1993 年老挝政府向外国投资开放电力行业以来，水电已成为老挝的主要出口产品之一。

Some of the laborers living in these dorms will presumably work at the new cement plant further up the road, just outside the village of Nam Veun. Blue and white silos tower over a billboard celebrating the plant’s inauguration, and you can find similar silos downstream from Oudomxay, where the energy company ChinaPower is building a large hydroelectric dam. It’s the latest in a string of dams China has constructed on the upper Mekong River. Since the Lao government opened the power sector to foreign investment in 1993, hydroelectricity has become one of Laos’s primary exports.

从水泥厂到工人的工作服，与铁路相关的一切都是蓝白配色，并印有普通话。这让他们与镇上的其他地方在视觉和地理上都相差甚远。中国人通常“喜欢生活在自己的圈子里，不太善于与当地同事交往”，正如中国驻内罗毕大使馆 2012 年发布的一份备忘录所明确指出的那样。

Everything related to the railway, from the cement plants to the workers’ jumpsuits, is branded with the same blue and white color scheme and emblazoned with Mandarin characters. It sets them far apart from the rest of the town, visually and geographically. The Chinese generally “prefer to live together in their own circle and are not so sociable with their fellow local employees,” as a 2012 memo put out by the Chinese embassy in Nairobi bluntly stated.

在去往博丁的路上，我们走错了路——在一个道路如此稀少的国家，走错路并不容易，但我们还是走了过去。我们最终来到了一个破旧的村庄，名叫纳泰。一群妇女坐在路边，我们停下来问路。她们在午后的阳光下喝着国产啤酒。当我告诉她们我来老挝的原因时，她们异口同声地抱怨道。现在中国人到处都是，而且很粗鲁，她们说。其中一位甚至没有先和当地村长交谈就开了一家小餐馆，妇女们认为这是不尊重的表现。“他们只是因为有权力而为所欲为，”其中一位妇女挥舞着她的啤酒说道。“他们来这里就是为了赚钱。”

On the way to Boten we took a wrong turn—not easy to do in a country with so few roads, but we managed. We ended up in a threadbare village called Nateuy. A group of women was sitting on the side of the road and we stopped to ask directions. They were getting plastered on domestic beer in the early afternoon sun. When I told them why I was in Laos, they groaned in unison. The Chinese were everywhere now, and rude, they said. One of them had even opened a small restaurant without talking to the local village chief first, which the women took as a sign of disrespect. “They just do what they want because they have power,” said one of them, wielding her beer. “They just come here and make money.”

我们在他们抱怨的那家餐馆停了下来。店主领着我们经过一排玻璃罐，里面装满了植物根和漂浮在清澈液体中的死龟。我们是唯一的顾客，但她似乎不耐烦地等着我们点菜。墙上贴着饭菜的照片，她牵着我的胳膊肘，领着我从一张照片看到另一张照片，就像在画廊里一样。麻辣豆腐和米饭很快就端上来了，她盯着我们吃。这完全不像在老挝人开的餐馆吃饭的体验，那是一种闲聊和寒暄的懒散活动。我能理解文化规范的分歧会让老挝人感到不受尊重。

We stopped at the restaurant they’d complained about. The proprietor ushered us past a row of glass jugs filled with roots and dead turtles floating in clear liquid. We were the only customers, but she seemed impatient for us to order. Photographs of meals were posted on the walls, and she led me by the elbow from photo to photo as if in a gallery. Spicy mapo tofu and rice arrived quickly, and she stared as we ate. It was not at all like the experience of eating at a Lao-owned establishment, a lazy affair of chit-chat and pleasantries. I could see how the rift in cultural norms would leave the Lao feeling disrespected.

老挝丛林中一个半废弃的前赌场小镇并不是 Callan Cheng 想象中的自己 29 岁的生活之地。然而，他现在却在磨丁，蜷缩在伞下，走出了无人的免税商场，在那里，他以采购员的身份在一间不起眼的办公室里工作，办公室高高地矗立着香水和化妆品的货架。威士忌。已经连续下了一个星期的雨了，虽然他的公寓楼离办公室只有五分钟的步行路程，但每天从工作地点到家穿过泥泞的街道还是让人感到沮丧。

A half-abandoned former casino town in the Lao jungle is not where Callan Cheng imagined he’d be living at twenty-nine. Yet here he was in Boten, huddled beneath an umbrella, exiting the shopperless duty-free mall, where he worked as a buyer in a nondescript office high above the aisles of perfume and whiskey. It had been raining for a week straight, and though his apartment building was only a five-minute walk from his office, the slog from work to home through the muddy streets was a daily depressant.

至少程先生住在五楼。如果连续几天下雨，一楼和二楼的公寓就变成了发霉、潮湿的玻璃容器。他甚至有自己的房间——这是中层管理人员罕见的福利之一——房间设计得像廉价汽车旅馆，地板是硬瓷砖，墙壁是光秃秃的，装饰是亮漆。2014 年，他被总部位于昆明的中国公司磨丁经济区开发建设集团聘用，从那以后就一直住在这里。程先生的公司从那里远程管理磨丁市。“我们控制着整个磨丁，整个城市，”他说。实际上，该公司就是市政府，管理着磨丁的税收和财政、公用事业、电信基础设施、卫生、紧急服务、酒店、市场，当然还有免税商场。同样，几乎所有在磨丁工作的人都领着该公司的工资。老挝公共部门的参与度很低。“他们授权我们来管理这些事情，”程先生说。

At least Cheng lived on the fifth floor. The first and second floor flats devolved into moldy, moisture-locked terrariums when it rained for days on end like this. He even had his own room—one of the rare perks of middle management—a budget-motel motif of hard-tile flooring, bare walls, and shiny lacquered decor. He’d been living here since 2014, when he was hired by the Boten Economic Zone Development and Construction Group, a Chinese company headquartered in Kunming. From there, Cheng’s company manages the city of Boten remotely. “We control all of Boten, the entire city,” he says. In effect, the company is the municipal government, administering Boten’s taxes and finances, public utilities, telecommunications infrastructure, sanitation, emergency services, its hotels, markets and, of course, the duty-free mall. Likewise, nearly everyone working in Boten is on the company payroll. The Lao public sector has minimal involvement. “They’ve authorized us to take care of things,” says Cheng.

1993 年，当边境口岸在磨丁设立时，这一地区还是一片人烟稀少的无主之 地， 到处都是分散的、孤立的山区定居点。21 世纪初，赌场的出现让这座城市变成了喧闹闹闹的狂欢节，但由于专注于非法娱乐，它并没有真正发展成为一个贸易中心。2009 年，中泰贸易额只有区区 2000 万美元。当时的一份外交电报描述了它作为半个小时内，“边境口岸异常安静……只有一辆卡车和一辆公共汽车进入中国”。

When the border crossing was established in Boten in 1993, this region was a thinly settled terra nullius of scattered, isolated mountain settlements. In the early 2000s, the arrival of the casinos turned the city into a braying haunted carnival, but with the focus on illicit fun it didn’t really develop as a trade hub. In 2009, a paltry $20 million in Sino-Thai commerce moved through here. A diplomatic cable from that period described it as a “remarkably quiet border crossing . . . with one truck and one bus coming into China” over the course of half an hour.

十年后，随着掘进机开辟一条横跨边境的新铁路隧道，中国和东盟每年的贸易额接近 5000 亿美元，磨丁正逐渐转型为一个商业中心——中国通往东南亚的交通枢纽，也是一带一路的重点发展区域。你可以在磨丁边境外的荒野中看到这座城市新意义的分支，那里闪现着外来的现代化：PetroLao 加油站、灰泥宾馆，以及最奇怪的：一个摆满华丽卧室家具的富丽堂皇的家具陈列室。部分森林已被砍伐，为停满平板卡车的泥泞停车场腾出空间。

A decade later, with boring machines slicing a new railway tunnel across the border and trade between China and ASEAN approaching half a trillion dollars per year, Boten is reincarnating, bit by bit, as a commercial hub—a transport link for China into Southeast Asia, and a One Belt One Road priority holding. You can see offshoots of the city’s new relevance in the wilderness just beyond its borders, where flashes of alien modernity have materialized: PetroLao gas stations, stucco guesthouses, and the weirdest: a palatial furniture showroom fully stocked with flashy bedroom sets. Sections of the forest have been clear-cut to make way for muddy parking lots filled with flatbed trucks.

磨丁的入口处有一个海关检查站，确认你已离开老挝，但实际上并未真正离开。过了检查站，丛林的沉闷立刻消失了，取而代之的是拥挤不堪、车水马龙的长途卡车，它们正奋力驶向中国边境。车流绕过了磨丁几乎空无一人的核心区。从远处看，在正午的薄雾中，磨丁的淡色天际线就像是一座褪色的佛罗里达度假小镇。近看，它看起来就像是一座人口暴跌后正在缓慢复苏的城市。

At the entrance to Boten is a customs checkpoint, confirmation that you’re exiting Laos without actually leaving. Beyond the checkpoint, the jungle torpor immediately evaporates, replaced by a grinding, gridlocked sea of long-haul trucks fighting their way toward the Chinese border. The queue of traffic bypasses Boten’s mostly empty core. From afar, in the midday haze, Boten’s pastel skyline could pass for a faded Florida resort town. Up close, it looks like what it is: a city slowly regenerating after a population crash.

城里的一些旧企业已经恢复生机。程先生的免税商场曾经是一家迪斯科舞厅，里面有万宝路和尊尼获加，但几乎没有顾客。穿着笔挺黑色西装的年轻中国店员在安静的过道里徘徊，就像波普艺术博物馆的讲解员一样。

Around town, some of the former enterprises have been revived. Cheng’s cavernous duty-free mall, once a disco, contains Marlboros and Johnnie Walker, but virtually no customers. Young Chinese clerks in sharp black suits wander the quiet aisles like docents in a pop art museum.

沿着街道，来到皇家景兰酒店，庭院喷泉里满是泥土，杂草丛生的热带植物爬上了建筑的外墙。一辆生锈的雅马哈摩托车躺在杂草丛生的花坛里，一辆以前用来接送客人游览城市的有轨电车的四个轮胎都生锈了。大堂里的空气凉爽潮湿。酒店的后墙上缺了一块墙，洞口映出远处的森林，就像一幅史前生活的立体模型。大多数房间都封上了门，但有几个房间被人闯入过，其中一间房间的床垫上放着皱巴巴的床上用品，还有一位未付钱的客人刚吃完饭的残羹剩饭。在三楼的日光浴室里，湿漉漉的衬衫挂在天花板管道上的衣架上，在阳光下晒干。被洗劫一空的主管办公室里散落着酒店管理的琐碎资料：员工日程表、用普通话打印的报告，桌子上打开了一本中英词典，好像它的主人查了一个单词，就离开了房间，再也没有回来。

Down the street, at the Royal Jingland Hotel, the courtyard fountain is filled with muck, and overgrown tropical gardens are climbing the building’s exterior walls. A rusting Yamaha motorbike lies in a weedy flowerbed, and one of the electric trams formerly used to shuttle guests around town rusts out on four flat tires. In the lobby, the air is cool and moist. There’s a chunk missing from the hotel’s back wall, and the gaping hole frames the forest beyond like a diorama of prehistoric life. Most of the rooms are sealed, but a few have been broken into, including one with rumpled bedding on the mattress and the remnants of a nonpaying guest’s recently eaten meal. In a third-floor solarium, damp shirts dangle from hangers on a ceiling pipe, drying in the sun. A ransacked supervisor’s office is strewn with the minutiae of hotel management: employee schedules, reports typed up in Mandarin, and a Chinese-English dictionary opened on the desk, as if its owner looked up a word, left the room, and never returned.

磨丁为数不多的热门景点之一是前黄金赌场，现已改建成一家闪闪发光的玉石商场，挤满了寻求优惠的中国顾客。一名保安犹豫着是否让这位胡子拉碴、身穿脏兮兮的黑色 T 恤的西方人进去，但一位年轻的女店员跳起来救了我：来自云南的王婷婷。她大步向我走来，伸出胳膊，像老朋友一样咧嘴笑着。我来自哪里？纽约！太令人兴奋了！我在磨丁做什么？一本书！有意思！她带我进去，进门时用普通话对保安嘟囔了几句，然后转过身来，开玩笑地翻了个白眼，好像在说：“你能相信那家伙吗？”

One of Boten’s few hotspots is in the former Golden Casino, readapted as a luminous jade emporium buzzing with a deal-seeking Chinese clientele. A security guard hesitates to admit the unshaven Westerner in the dirty black t-shirt, but a young shopgirl bounds to my rescue: Wang Tingting from Yunnan Province. She strides toward me, arm outstretched, grinning like an old friend. Where do I come from? New York! How exciting! What am I doing in Boten? A book! Interesting! She spirits me inside, muttering something in Mandarin to the guard as we enter before turning to me and playfully rolling her eyes as if to say, “Can you believe that guy?”

王先生带着企业公关人员优雅而亲切的态度，带我参观了市场。LED 灯下，数以千计的手镯、项链、戒指和护身符闪闪发光，它们全都是用缅甸冲突频发的克钦邦开采的玉石雕刻而成的。“只选用最好的矿石，”王先生向我保证，“而且价格适中。”

With the polished affability of a corporate publicist, Wang whisks me through the marketplace. Thousands of bracelets, necklaces, rings, and amulets glint beneath LED lights, all of them carved from jade mined in Myanmar’s conflict-riven Kachin State. “Only the best minerals,” Wang assures me, “and something for every ability to pay.”

王女士有着一颗流浪者的灵魂。二十出头时，她移居泰国，爱上了这个国家，并在那里生活了几年。“我会说泰语，我想回去学习泰语，”她说。在我们见面的六个月前，她搬到了磨丁，希望从高速铁路带来的繁荣中获利。她说，获得在磨丁工作的许可并不难，这要归功于跨境合作协议，该协议加快了希望在这里工作的中国公民的许可。

Wang has a wanderer’s soul. In her early twenties she moved to Thailand, fell in love with the country, and ended up spending several years there. “I speak Thai, and I want to go back and use it,” she says. Six months prior to our meeting she had moved to Boten, hoping to cash in on the boom she believes will inevitably arrive with the high-speed railway. Getting the go-ahead to work in Boten wasn’t hard, she says, thanks to the cross-border cooperation pact that expedites permissions for Chinese nationals who want to work here.

王女士在老挝轻而易举地就获得了这份工作，这恰恰是经济特区的意义所在：消除阻碍开展业务的繁文缛节。经济特区主要是一种简化投资的机制。但正如王婷婷所证明的那样，即使是一个卑微的店员也可以利用经济特区的福利。“一旦铁路建成，这里将是一个重要的工作场所，”她告诉我。

The ease with which Wang got the job in Laos is exactly the point of a special economic zone: to eliminate the red tape that delays getting down to business. SEZs chiefly serve as a mechanism for streamlining investment. But as Wang Tingting proves, even a humble store clerk can leverage the perks of an SEZ. “Once the railway is built, this will be an important place to work,” she informs me.

程先生也认为，那些愿意在这里待上几年的人最终会得到回报。“我不喜欢住在磨丁，”他说。“对我来说，这里太荒凉了。”他希望有一天能回到喧闹嘈杂的昆明，他是那里现代中国传统中唯一的孩子。或者更好的是，回到他梦想中的繁华上海。不过，目前，他正在等待他会花时间研究。“我认为五年后，磨丁会成为一座大城市，”程说。“虽然不大，但比现在好。我认为会有超过 10 万人，游客和做生意的人。这是中国人前往东盟的铁路第一站，因此对物流来说很重要。我希望有机会参与它的发展。”

Cheng agrees that those willing to spend a few years here will eventually be rewarded. “I don’t like living in Boten,” he says. “It’s too deserted for me.” He hopes to someday return to the cacophonous clang of Kunming, where he was raised an only child in the modern Chinese tradition. Or better yet, glitzy Shanghai, his city of dreams. For now, however, he’s biding his time. “I think in five years, Boten will be a big city,” says Cheng. “Not huge, but better than now. I think there will be over 100,000 people, tourists, people doing business. It’s the first station on the railway for Chinese people going to ASEAN, so it will be important for logistics. I want to have a chance to be part of its development.”

在市中心，这一开发项目初具规模。三座浇筑混凝土的塔楼在起重机的杂乱中拔地而起，构成了翻新后的磨丁的天际线。据程先生介绍，重建计划要求在市中心建造总共六座建筑，它们将构成某种形式的微型中央商务区。在施工现场张贴的效果图中可以看到其中一些建筑：俗气的罪恶之城已经消失，取而代之的是明亮、健康的林荫大道和咖啡馆街景。

In the city center, this development is beginning to take shape. A trio of poured-concrete towers, the fledgling skyline of the renovated Boten, rise amid a tangle of cranes. According to Cheng, the redevelopment plan calls for a total of six downtown buildings that will constitute some form of miniature central business district. Some of these buildings can be seen in renderings posted at the construction site: The tawdry sin city has vanished, replaced by a bright, wholesome streetscape of boulevards and cafés.

磨丁最初被出售时被描绘成一座国际化程度最高的现代化城市，目前由一家中国财团开发，据说特许经营期为 99 年。“对于那些拥有资本、关系和能力的人来说，边境国家的无政府状态是一个巨大的机遇，”本·罗伦斯在《 荆棘之城》一书中写道。对于磨丁的新机会主义者来说，这个新兴的物流中心承诺了更多：有机会在最具前景的边境之一利用大规模的全球贸易计划获利。

Boten is sketched as originally sold: a most internationally modernized city, now in development by a Chinese consortium under a reported ninety-nine-year concession. “The anarchy of the border country is, for those with capital and connections and the ability to exploit it, a giant opportunity,” writes Ben Rawlence in the book City of Thorns. For Boten’s new opportunists, the fledgling logistics hub promises this and more: the chance to cash in on a massive global trade initiative at one of its most promising frontiers.

免税商场无人收银机旁堆放着精美的传单，上面描绘着这个边境地区的未来，还有经过改造的磨丁的效果图，磨丁是一座拥有高铁的幸福城市。传单中央是一张照片习近平主席的头像下方是世界地图。虚线从中国延伸至亚洲、欧洲和非洲。对“一带一路”取得成功至关重要的城市都标有星星：新加坡、蒙巴萨、德黑兰、科伦坡、莫斯科、鹿特丹和老挝北部的一个小城市，这个小城市恰好位于高铁路线上，其位置用中文标注，标有最大的一颗星星。

That frontier’s future is depicted on glossy flyers stacked by the unmanned cash registers at the duty-free mall, with renderings of the new-and-improved Boten, a happy city with a high-speed train. In the center of the flyers is a photo of President Xi, and below him, a map of the world. Dotted lines lead outward from China to points throughout Asia, Europe, and Africa. The cities key to making One Belt One Road a success are marked with stars: Singapore, Mombasa, Tehran, Colombo, Moscow, Rotterdam, and a tiny city in northern Laos, perfectly placed on the route of a high-speed railway, its location labeled in Mandarin and marked with the biggest star of them all.

双赢

Win-Win

中国希望世界爱它，而这往往始于让各国相信中国并不可怕。这很难让人接受，据估计，中国中国每年在软实力项目上花费 100 亿美元。为此，北京在世界各地建立了数百所孔子学院，教授外国人中国语言和历史，并在西方推广其新华社。

China wants the world to love it, which often starts with convincing countries that China isn’t scary. It’s been a tough sell, and by one estimate the country spends $10 billion per year on its soft power programs.
