To this end, Beijing has set up hundreds of Confucius Institutes around the world to teach foreigners Chinese language and history, and promoted its Xinhua news agency throughout the West.

但所有这些支出都未能让世界接受中国的方式。中国的软实力被其政权自身的威权主义和叙事控制的名声所玷污。2016 年，纽约时报广场的一块电子广告牌播放了一段视频，用轻快的音乐和诱人的蔚蓝海水和热带岛屿的图像捍卫中国在南海的主权。中国媒体报道称，这段视频“吸引了大量观众”，但实际上，它被广泛嘲笑为拙劣的宣传文章。这是北京的难题。

But all the spending has failed to endear the world to the Chinese way. Chinese soft power is tainted by the regime’s own authoritarianism and reputation for narrative control. In 2016, an electronic billboard in New York’s Times Square played a video defending China’s claims in the South China Sea using jaunty music and images of inviting azure water and tropical isles. Chinese media reported the video “appealed to a massive number of people,” but in reality, it was widely ridiculed as a ham-handed article of propaganda. This is Beijing’s conundrum.

因此，中国将其无与伦比的建设才能作为其首选的软实力策略。与美国一样，当今中国将其外交重点定位为造福全球的力量。所有发展都被认为是“双赢的”，相反的证据也无法推翻这一假设。但是，尽管中国的信息与西方相似，但其发展方式却明显不同，一带一路涉及的国家才刚刚开始适应这一现实。作为帮助较贫穷国家实现现代化的回报，中国往往希望获得对这些国家部分地区的事实上的控制权。不是殖民那部分地区——只是将其货币化。不是拥有它本身，而是以一种让中国直接受益的方式获取和利用它。

So China has turned to its unparalleled knack for construction as its soft power tactic of choice. Like the United States, China today frames its foreign priorities as a force for global good. All development is said to be “win-win,” and evidence to the contrary won’t debunk this hypothesis. But while China’s message echoes the West’s, its methods of development are notably different, a reality the countries touched by One Belt One Road are just beginning to settle into. In return for helping poorer countries modernize, China often expects to be granted de facto control over a piece of those countries. Not to colonize that piece—simply to monetize it. Not to own it, per se, but to access and utilize it in a way that benefits China directly.

磨丁黄金城和高铁是两个截然不同的项目，但有一点相似：它们都是从一个国家向另一个国家进行局部政府控制权转移。在这些项目周边，老挝不同程度地放弃了国家主权，以换取现代化，让中国对其大片土地拥有管辖权。

Boten Golden City and the high-speed railway are very different projects, but they’re similar in one respect: They’re localized transfers of governmental control from one country to another. Within the perimeters of these sites, Laos, to varying degrees, has relinquished its national sovereignty in exchange for modernization, giving China jurisdiction over a substantial amount of its land.

当中国把磨丁变成一个迷你澳门时，磨丁即将超越德国成为世界最大出口国。经济增长势头强劲平均每年增长 11%。这要归功于异常庞大的劳动力和邓小平（1978 年至 1989 年中国最高领导人）的经济远见，但北京的强大投资于该国现在著名的基础设施项目。到 2010 年，中国政府大约有一半的国内生产总值（GDP）用于此类投资，这一比例比任何其他国家以往的支出都要高。

When China turned Boten into a mini Macau, it was on the cusp of surpassing Germany as the world’s top exporter. Economic growth was humming along at an annual average of 11 percent. An unusually large workforce and the economic foresight of Deng Xiaoping, China’s paramount leader from 1978 to 1989, was to thank, but so were Beijing’s weighty investments in the country’s now famous infrastructure projects. By 2010, the Chinese government was spending roughly half of its GDP on these types of investments, a greater share than any other country had ever spent before.

大手笔的支出让中国成为世界历史上最富有成效的建筑国，但同时也建造了比实际需要更多的工厂、机场和公寓楼。由于国内建设过多，中国开始寻找其他地方来浇筑混凝土；这种卸载过剩产能的愿望是“一带一路”倡议的动机之一。这也是中国开始为其他国家建造火车和铁路的原因，努力将自己定位为全球铁路所有项目的首选总承包商。

The spending spree gave China the mantle of the most prolific builder the world had ever seen, but also more factories, airports, and apartment buildings than it really needs. Overbuilt at home, China started looking for other places to pour its concrete; this desire to offload excess capacity is one of the motivations for the One Belt One Road initiative. It’s also why China has begun building trains and railways for other countries, working to position itself as the world’s go-to general contractor for all things rail.

中国将此视为“铁路外交”，这是一项于 2011 年正式启动的战略，旨在向世界各地的交通部门推销中国的铁路硬件和技术。李克强总理是这项努力的首要推销员，他从罗马尼亚跳到印度，大肆宣扬中国高铁是一种交通解决方案和经济福音。他带着一辆闪闪发光的模型火车，即海豚车头的 CRH380A，这是中国设计的，日本抱怨它是其标志性新干线的仿制品。2014 年，他访问了亚的斯亚贝巴，此后非洲联盟签署了一项行动计划，到 2063 年将非洲所有主要城市都通上高铁。2015 年 5 月，他前往巴西，说服当时的总统迪尔玛·罗塞夫修建一条穿越亚马逊雨林的横贯大陆的铁路。此时，中国已与近30个国家就高铁项目进行洽谈，并计划到2020年将海外铁路合同数量增加一倍。

China considers this “railway diplomacy,” a strategy formally launched in 2011 to sell Chinese rail hardware and technology to transport ministries around the world. Premier Li Keqiang is the effort’s foremost pitchman, hopscotching from Romania to India, talking up Chinese high-speed trains as a transit solution and an economic boon. He travels with a shiny model train, the porpoise-nosed CRH380A, a Chinese design that Japan has complained is a knockoff of its iconic Shinkansen. He traveled to Addis Ababa in 2014, after which the African Union signed an action plan to connect every major city in Africa to high-speed rail by 2063. He went to Brazil in May 2015 to convince then-President Dilma Rousseff of the need to cut a transcontinental railway through the Amazon rainforest. By that point, China was in talks with nearly thirty countries about high-speed rail projects, with plans to double its overseas rail contracts by the year 2020.

所有这些竞争都发生在中国崛起为世界铁路行业顶峰的背景下。2015 年，全球铁路收入的 41% 流向了中国公司。同年，中国合并了两家国有铁路车辆制造商，成立了仅次于通用电气的第二大工业公司——中国中车股份有限公司 (CRRC)。该公司开始在世界各地销售火车，包括首次在美国销售，首先是与马萨诸塞州交通管理局 MBTA 签订了 5.66 亿美元的合同。

All this pitching has occurred amid China’s rise to the summit of the world’s rail industry. By 2015, 41 percent of global rail revenues were flowing to Chinese companies. That same year, China merged its two state-owned railcar manufacturers to create the second-largest industrial company after GE, the China Railway Rolling Stock Corporation (CRRC). It began peddling its trains everywhere, including, for the first time, in the United States, starting with a $566 million contract with the Massachusetts transit authority, the MBTA.

在中国加入之前，长期资金短缺的马萨诸塞湾交通管理局只是打算修复其旧地铁车厢，其中一些车厢已经嘎吱作响地运行了 46 年。但中国中车竞标项目成本比最接近的竞争对手低 1 亿多美元，因此从中国购买新车比翻新旧车更划算。马萨诸塞湾交通局为其红线和橙线订购了 284 辆地铁车厢，2017 年 4 月，市政厅广场揭幕了三分之二大小的模型。这些模型从北京的天津港运来，用巨大的橙色蝴蝶结包裹着，迪斯科时代的木质镶板​​和破旧的吸菌内饰都不见了。通过翻译、中车代表安忠义感谢人群“相信我们有能力领导这个项目”，而一位名叫 Vivian Luo 的地铁街头艺人则拉起了小提琴。新车将使马萨诸塞州湾交通管理局将列车间隔缩短至三分钟，使不堪重负的系统每小时的运力增加 10,000 名乘客。

Before China came in, the chronically cash-strapped MBTA was simply going to rehab its old subway cars, some of which had been creaking along for 46 years. But CRRC’s bid for the project—over $100 million lower than the closest competitor’s—made it more financially sensible for the agency to purchase new cars from China than to spruce up the old ones. The MBTA ordered 284 subway cars for its red and orange lines, and in April 2017, a two-thirds size mockup was unveiled at City Hall Plaza. Shipped from Beijing’s Tianjin Port and wrapped in a giant orange bow, gone was the disco-era wood paneling and worn, bacteria-absorbent upholstery. Through an interpreter, CRRC representative An Zhongyi thanked the crowd for “believing in our ability to lead this project,” while a crop-topped subway busker named Vivian Luo played her violin. The new cars would allow the MBTA to cut intervals between trains to as little as three minutes, increasing the overwhelmed system’s capacity by 10,000 passengers per hour.

中国进军美国铁路市场，对习惯于依靠火车勉强维持运转的美国城市来说，是一个重大改变从 20 世纪 70 年代开始。马萨诸塞州匆忙与中国中车签订了第二份订单，订购另外 134 辆车，因为正如该州交通部长所说，“我们希望他们做我们的工作，我们不希望他们做别人的工作。”

China’s leap into the U.S. railway market was a game-changer for American cities accustomed to scraping by with trains from the 1970s. Massachusetts rushed through a second order with CRRC for another 134 cars because, as the state’s transportation secretary put it, “We want them to do ours, and we don’t want them to do someone else’s.”

但中国中车已经在做别人的事情了。它与费城和洛杉矶签订了合同，并达成协议更换芝加哥一半的列车——这是它有史以来从发达国家获得的最大订单。一些当地政客对中国入侵发出了必要的抱怨，但事实是，多年来没有一家美国公司在全球客运列车市场上具有竞争力，而且无论如何，中国中车正在美国建造或投资工厂，勤劳的美国人（其中一些人在中国接受过培训）将自己组装列车。对于这些交通运输机构来说，中国更像是救星而不是威胁，使他们能够以前所未有的价格用最先进的技术更新他们的系统。

But CRRC was already doing someone else’s. It signed contracts with Philadelphia and Los Angeles, and struck a deal to replace half of Chicago’s fleet—its biggest order ever from a developed country. A few local pols scored points with the requisite grumblings about Chinese encroachment, but the truth was, no American company had been competitive on the global passenger railcar market in years, and in any case, CRRC was building or investing in U.S.-based factories where hardworking Americans, some of them trained in China, would assemble the trains themselves. For these transit agencies, China was more of a savior than a threat, enabling them to update their systems with state-of-the-art technology at a price point they’d never seen.

这种人人受益的局面正是中国希望世界看到其铁路外交，以及整个“一带一路”计划的方式。“现在中国已经发展起来了，轮到我们做出贡献了，”中国亚洲基础设施投资基金的负责人如是说。班克在 2017 年的一次采访中慷慨地表示，铁路、公路、机场都是公共产品，它们推动增长，改善人们的实际生活，中国希望成为世界友好邻里建设者。2014 年，中国对外投资流量猛增超过 1000 亿美元，比上年增长 14%。而且这些资金不仅流向中等收入国家。中国在发展中国家的投资增长了三倍。欧盟，并增加了对美国 24% 的支出。所有据了解，当年共有156个国家和地区接受了中国投资。

This everybody-wins dynamic is exactly how China wants the world to see its rail diplomacy, and by extension, the sprawling One Belt One Road initiative as a whole. “Now that China has developed, it is our turn to contribute,” is how the head of China’s Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank magnanimously put it in a 2017 interview. Railways, highways, airports—these are public goods. They drive growth and improve real people’s lives, and China hopes to be known as the world’s friendly neighborhood builder of them. In 2014, China’s outbound investment flows surged past $100 billion, up 14 percent from the year before. And the money didn’t only go to middle-income countries. It tripled its investments in the European Union and boosted its spending in the U.S. by 24 percent. All told, 156 countries and regions received Chinese investment that year.

虽然这种规模是史无前例的，但通过基础设施进行外交几十年来一直是中国外交的策略。20 世纪 70 年代初，与苏联和西方关系疏远的毛泽东为坦桑尼亚和赞比亚修建了坦赞铁路，以加强中国与非洲的关系。他选择了一个合适的时机来做这件事。世界银行等机构正在扩大其关注范围，包括医疗和教育等社会福利项目。与此同时，中国开始出口基础设施，更多的是为了交朋友而不是赚钱。即使在那时，主席也把坦赞铁路项目描述为一个陷入困境的国家送给另一个国家的礼物。“你们有困难，我们也有困难。”“我们愿意这样做，”毛泽东告诉两国领导人。“为了帮助你们修铁路，我们愿意放弃自己修铁路。”

Though this scope is unprecedented, diplomacy via infrastructure has been a Chinese diplomatic tactic for decades. In the early 1970s, Mao Zedong, estranged from both the Soviets and the West, built the TAZARA Railway for Tanzania and Zambia to shore up Chinese ties to Africa. He picked an opportune moment to do so. Institutions like the World Bank were broadening their focus to include social welfare rubrics like health and education. China, meanwhile, began exporting infrastructure, more to make friends than money. Even then, the Chairman framed the TAZARA project as a gift from one struggling nation to another. “You have difficulties as we do,” Mao told the leaders of both countries. “To help you build the railway, we are willing to forsake building railways for ourselves.”

三十年后，当崛起的北京主办 2008 年夏季奥运会时，火炬传递非洲之旅从达累斯萨拉姆的坦赞铁路火车站开始。这一象征意义十分强烈。距离中国建造该火车站已有三十三年，当时中国和坦桑尼亚都是勉强维持生计的第三世界兄弟。如今，中国已成为世界超级大国，仍在为其非洲朋友建设大型项目，而非洲朋友仍处于低收入国家行列。火炬传递之旅追溯了中国在坦桑尼亚投资的路线，终点是 2007 年用中国资金建造的国家体育场。这是一次致敬，也是一次提醒——公开统计“中国无私援助的历史证据”正如中国国务院在北京发表的一份白皮书巧妙地指出的那样，“中国将向非洲提供更多援助”。

Three decades later, when an ascendant Beijing hosted the 2008 Summer Games, it started the torch relay’s Africa run at the TAZARA train station in Dar es Salaam. The symbolism was potent. It had been thirty-three years since China built the terminal, back when it and Tanzania were third-world brethren barely scratching by. Now China was the world’s eclipsing superpower and still building megaprojects for its African friend, which still languishes in the lower-income country bracket. The torch relay literally traced the path of China’s investment in Tanzania, ending at the National Stadium built with Chinese money in 2007. It was a tribute, but also a reminder—a public tallying of the “historical evidence of China’s selfless help to Africa,” as a white paper issued by the State Council in Beijing tactfully put it.

如今，中国在东非铺设的铁轨数量比以往任何时候都多。2017 年 5 月 31 日，当中国建造的内罗毕-蒙巴萨列车首次运行——比原计划提前了一年——五彩纸屑在微风中飘扬。总统乌胡鲁·肯雅塔直截了当地将该项目与之前的殖民铁路区分开来，特别是由英国建造、脱轨频发的“疯狂快车”。肯雅塔自豪地说：“我们现在庆祝的不是疯狂快车，而是马达拉卡快车，它将在未来一百年重塑肯尼亚的故事。”

Today, China is laying more tracks than ever across East Africa. When the Chinese-built Nairobi-Mombasa train made its inaugural run on May 31, 2017—a year ahead of schedule—clouds of confetti swirled in the breeze. President Uhuru Kenyatta bluntly distinguished the project from the colonial railways that came before it, specifically the British-built, derailment-prone “Lunatic Express.” “We now celebrate not the Lunatic Express, but the Madaraka Express,” Kenyatta said proudly, “that will begin to reshape the story of Kenya for the next hundred years.”

但话音刚落，分析人士就开始争论这条铁路的后果。这条铁路会像肯雅塔承诺的那样重塑肯尼亚的未来，还是会颠覆其经济？铁路外交的接受国政府有时会发现，他们与中国的新“伙伴关系”让中国立即成为他们最大的债权国。马达拉卡特快铁路由中国进出口银行提供 38 亿美元贷款建造，这导致肯尼亚的债务占其 GDP 的一半以上。这是这就是为什么世界银行在 2013 年拒绝为该项目提供资金，认为修建从首都到海岸的标准轨距铁路没有“经济或财务理由”。

But scarcely had the words left his mouth that analysts were debating the railway’s consequences. Would it reshape Kenya’s future, as Kenyatta promised, or capsize its economy? Governments on the receiving end of railway diplomacy sometimes find that their new “partnership” with China has instantly made the People’s Republic their biggest creditor. The Madaraka Express was built with a $3.8 billion loan from China’s Export-Import Bank that nudged Kenya’s debt above half of its GDP. This is why the World Bank declined to finance the project in 2013, concluding there was no “economic or financial case” for a standard-gauge railway from the capital city to the coast.

当然，这也是 1991 年反对修建上海地铁的同一家世界银行。但考虑到国家资产负债表，一些合理的怀疑是合理的。即使是低价高铁也存在经济和技术挑战，这也是中国尽管做出了努力，却仍未完成的原因。国外高铁项目。自 2015 年以来，由中国牵头建设的一条连接雅加达和万隆的印尼高铁项目陷入了预算和土地征用问题。中国为墨西哥、巴西和美国修建高铁的交易都失败了，通常是因为最终这些项目被认为不是完全必要的。但中国并不负责决定其他国家是否真的需要高铁，而是负责向这些国家出售高铁。今年 1 月2017年，惠誉评级发布报告警告称，“一带一路”某些方面“可能并非旨在解决最紧迫的基础设施需求”，而是“中国扩大全球影响力和缓解国内产能过剩的努力”。

Of course, this is the same World Bank that argued against building a Shanghai subway in 1991. But with national balance sheets at stake, some healthy skepticism is warranted. The economic and technical challenges of even cut-rate high-speed rail are why, despite its efforts, China still hasn’t completed a high-speed rail project abroad. A Chinese-led high-speed link connecting Jakarta with Bandung in Indonesia has been mired in budget and land-acquisition problems since 2015. Deals for China to build high-speed rail for Mexico, Brazil, and the U.S. have all collapsed, often because in the end the projects were deemed not entirely necessary. But China isn’t in the business of determining whether other countries really need high-speed rail, it’s in the business of selling those countries high-speed rail regardless. In January 2017, Fitch Ratings released a report warning that some aspects of One Belt One Road “might not be aimed at addressing the most pressing infrastructure needs,” but instead at “China’s efforts to extend its global influence and relieve domestic overcapacity.”

这一点显而易见。尽管中国声称这只是“轮到我们做出贡献了”，但“一带一路”是一项高风险的地缘政治计划，旨在增强和巩固中国中国的高铁项目不仅是一项战略，而且是一项普通项目。中国国务院的一份新闻稿明确指出，“高铁是一项战略，而不仅仅是一项普通项目。”从本质上讲，战略项目不一定是为了盈利而设计的——它们可能会被当作亏损项目，以服务于长期目标。对于中国来说，这些损失已经计入预算。但对于与中国合作建设高铁的较贫穷国家来说，当宏伟梦想变成无用之物时，积累的债务可能是毁灭性的。

That much should be obvious. Despite China’s claim that it is simply “our turn to contribute,” One Belt One Road is a high-stakes geopolitical game plan to augment and fortify Chinese power. A press release from the State Council of China notes with clarity that “high-speed rail is a strategy rather than just a normal project.” By their very nature, strategic projects aren’t necessarily designed to turn a profit—they may be written off as loss leaders in service of a longer-term goal. For China, these losses are baked into the budget. But for the poorer countries partnering with China to build them, the debt amassed when big dreams become white elephants can be ruinous.

以斯里兰卡为例。这个岛国刚刚摆脱了内战，急需基础设施，而中国非常乐意伸出援手。它向斯里兰卡政府贷款 3 亿美元用于建设海港，并建造了附近有一个华丽的新机场。但海港贷款的利率被鲨鱼咬伤的概率为 6.3%，而且机场利用率很低，以至于保安据报道，他们被雇用来防止当地野生动物把空荡荡的广场变成室内栖息地。

Take the case of Sri Lanka. Recently emerged from a grinding civil war, the island nation is desperate for infrastructure and China has been more than happy to lend a hand. It loaned the Sri Lankan government $300 million for a seaport and built a flashy new airport nearby. But the interest rate for the seaport loan was a sharkbite 6.3 percent, and the airport is so underutilized that guards were reportedly hired to prevent local wildlife from turning the empty concourse into an indoor habitat.

这项协议和其他类似协议导致斯里兰卡欠中国 80 亿美元，无法偿还。2015 年 3 月，中国外交部在新闻发布会上谈到这笔债务时，发言人建议斯里兰卡“妥善解决有关问题……以维护中斯友好大局”，这似乎带有一种不加掩饰的威胁。因此，斯里兰卡在经济上斯里兰卡被束缚，同意将中国刚刚“贡献”给斯里兰卡海岸的海港 80% 的股份交给北京，以换取免除部分债务。在公众抗议之后，这一股份减少了，但结果保持不变：北京控制了世界上战略位置最优越的深海港口之一。这笔对中国来说本应失败的交易的结果是“一带一路”地图上的另一颗明针，直接漂浮在连接亚洲、非洲和中东的海上航线上。

The deal and others like it left Sri Lanka owing China $8 billion it couldn’t repay. When the Chinese Foreign Ministry addressed this debt at a press gaggle in March 2015, one could detect a thinly veiled threat when the spokesperson advised Sri Lanka to “properly resolve relevant problems . . . in the overall interests of China-Sri Lanka friendliness.” And so, financially hogtied, Sri Lanka agreed to give Beijing an 80 percent stake in the seaport China had just “contributed” to Sri Lanka’s shores in exchange for forgiving some of its debt. This stake was reduced after public protests, but the outcome remained the same: Beijing got control of one of the most strategically placed deep-sea ports in the world. The result of a deal supposedly gone wrong for China was another pin in the Belt and Road map, floating directly in the path of the shipping lanes linking Asia, Africa, and the Middle East.

中国是否打算让斯里兰卡贷款协议自毁，以此来获得港口控制权？为了更好地了解北京的动机，我在新加坡会见了帕拉格·康纳。康纳的简历称他是一位“全球战略家”。他的简历是一份庄重的沙拉，包括特别顾问的荣誉、智库奖学金、畅销书、董事会成员和高级学位。但在现实生活中，他很随意，甚至有点傻乎乎的。他建议我们在新加坡市中心一家奢华的仿艺术装饰酒吧 Atlas 见面，他穿着短裤和人字拖，兴高采烈地违反了着装规定。沃尔芬一边烤着章鱼，一边把腿搭在皮椅的扶手上，他指出，虽然斯里兰卡前任政府与中国关系友好，但现任政府却顽固地抵制北京的提议。但在港口交易失败后，“斯里兰卡对中国的债务风险如此之高，他们别无选择，只能回到前任政府的亲华立场，”卡纳说。“这是狡猾的计划。”

Did China intend for the Sri Lankan loan deal to self-destruct as a way of acquiring control of the port? To better understand Beijing’s motives, I met with Parag Khanna in Singapore. Khanna’s bio describes him as a “global strategist.” His resumé is a gravitas salad of special advisory credits, think-tank fellowships, bestselling books, board affiliations, and advanced degrees. But in person he’s loose, even goofy. He suggested we meet at Atlas, an extravagant faux art deco bar in downtown Singapore, to which he arrived in shorts and flipflops in cheerful defiance of the dress code. Wolfing grilled octopus and throwing his leg over the arm of his leather chair, he notes that while the previous Sri Lankan government had been friendly with China, the current one had been stubbornly resistant to Beijing’s overtures. But after the port deal went south, “Sri Lanka’s debt exposure to China was so high, they had no choice but to go back to the pro-China stance of the government before them,” says Khanna. “That’s crafty planning.”

“我有一个方程式，用来衡量你的国家与中国的关系有多糟糕，”他说。这是一个简单的评估，旨在说明一个观点。“分子是你欠中国的债务，分母是你未偿还的总债务。结果是你的国家欠中国的债务份额。”数字越高，你就越“糟糕”。

“I have an equation I use to measure how fucked your country is in its relationship with China,” he says. It’s a back-of-the-napkin appraisal designed to make a point. “Your numerator is your debt to China, and your denominator is your total outstanding debt. The result is the share of your country’s debt owed to China.” The higher the number, the more you’re “fucked.”

中国贷款占斯里兰卡 650 亿美元国债总额的 80 亿美元。“很多国家都符合我的数学公式，”卡纳说。“这是设计好的。中国利用这些债务来获得它想要的其他东西。哦，你刚刚拖欠了还款？好吧，你必须以低价卖给我们你的下一个石油和天然气勘探特许权。否则你下一批主权债务将以人民币而不是美元发行。”

Loans from China comprise about $8 billion of Sri Lanka’s total $65 billion national debt. “A number of countries fall into my little mathematical formula,” says Khanna. “And that’s by design. China leverages this debt to get other things it wants. Oh, you just defaulted on your payment? Okay, you have to sell us your next oil and gas exploration concession at a fire sale price. Or your next tranche of sovereign debt issuance will be in renminbi instead of dollars.”

支持这一理论的人称之为“债务陷阱外交”，一位学者声称“中国正在采取措施确保各国无法摆脱债务。”斯里兰卡并不是第一个因中国慷慨解囊而陷入困境的国家。就在西北方向，55 美元的中巴经济走廊（CPEC）是一条连接中国和阿拉伯海的公路、铁路和能源基础设施网络，耗资 100 亿美元，它有可能让巴基斯坦陷入同样薄弱的财政困境。巴基斯坦一位前财政部长估计，CPEC 贷款可能会使该国的债务水平增加 140 亿美元，使其总债务达到 900 亿美元十亿美元。BMI 研究报告警告称，这可能使巴基斯坦陷入“与斯里兰卡目前所处的境地相似”的境地。这笔交易已经让中国获得了瓜达尔港 40 年的租约，对于任何希望确保其在波斯湾利益的国家来说，这都是一个极具战略意义的位置。

Proponents of this theory have labeled it “debt-trap diplomacy,” with one scholar alleging that “China is taking steps to ensure that countries will not be able to escape their debts.” Sri Lanka isn’t the first country to be backed against a wall by Chinese generosity. Just a tick northwest, the $55 billion China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), a web of roads, rail, and energy infrastructure linking China to the Arabian Sea, threatens to beckon Pakistan onto similarly thin fiscal ice. One of Pakistan’s former finance ministers estimates that CPEC loans could raise the country’s debt level by $14 billion, bringing it to a total of $90 billion. A BMI Research report warned that this could put Pakistan in a position “similar to the situation that Sri Lanka currently finds itself in.” Already, the deal has secured China a forty-year lease on Gwadar Port, a supremely strategic location for any country hoping to secure its interests in the Persian Gulf.

在卡纳看来，如果中国确实让其他国家背负了他们无法承受的债务，那只是精明的重商主义。“邻国贫穷落后、治理不善、需要基础设施，这不是中国的错，”他说。“四十年前中国自己就是那样的国家。中国要完成任务的唯一方法就是让它们进一步负债。”至于中国自以为是地宣称现在轮到它出力了，卡纳笑了。“没有仁慈的帝国。”狡猾和慈善真的不相容。

To Khanna, if China is indeed burdening countries with debt they can’t afford, that’s simply savvy mercantilism. “It’s not China’s fault its neighbors are poor and backward and badly governed and need infrastructure,” he says. “China itself was that country forty years ago. The only way for China to get things done is to indebt them further.” As for China’s feel-good assertion that it is simply its turn to contribute, Khanna laughs. “There’s no such thing as a benevolent empire.” Crafty and charitable don’t really mix.

然而，对于斯普林菲尔德市来说，马萨诸塞州湾交通局投资 9500 万美元、占地 20.4 万平方英尺的新铁路车厢工厂无疑给人一种两者兼而有之的感觉。可以肯定的是，该工厂是一项简单的商业投资，而不是让马萨诸塞州负债累累的战略尝试。但它是北京双赢口号在现实生活中发挥作用的一个例子。中国在该市前西屋电气工厂的旧址上开设了这家工厂，125 年前斯普林菲尔德制造了一辆美国第一辆燃气汽车。这是几十年来在后制造业城市中最大的工业项目，该城市在二十世纪末与布法罗和底特律一起慢慢衰落。2017 年 4 月，33 名工会钣金工人、工程师和主管登上飞机——这是他们前往吉林省接受培训的 30 小时旅程中的首班飞机——斯普林菲尔德市长称他们为劳动力先驱者。“在斯普林菲尔德建立制造业意味着回到未来，”他告诉前往中国的工人，“你们是其中的重要组成部分。”

And yet, for the city of Springfield, the MBTA’s new $95 million, 204,000-square-foot railcar factory certainly feels like a blend of both. To be sure, that plant is a straightforward business venture, not a strategic attempt to indebt the state of Massachusetts. But it stands as an example of Beijing’s win-win sloganeering playing out in real life. China opened the facility on the site of the city’s former Westinghouse Electric plant, 125 years after Springfield manufactured one of the United States’s first gas-powered cars. It’s the biggest industrial venture in decades to arrive in the post-manufacturing city, which slowly rusted out alongside the Buffalos and Detroits in the late twentieth century. In April 2017, as thirty-three union sheet metal workers, engineers, and supervisors boarded a flight—the first of three on their thirty-hour journey to Jilin Province for training—Springfield’s mayor referred to them as workforce pioneers. “It’s back to the future with establishing manufacturing in Springfield,” he told the China-bound workers, “and you are a big part of that.”

在真正的 《回到未来》 三部曲中，“未来”的马蒂·麦克弗莱在 2015 年为一家日本公司工作。（他的老板富士通先生通过传真解雇了他。）这部电影是该系列的第二部，于 1989 年上映，当时好莱坞流行地认为，普通美国人有朝一日也会为富士通先生工作。虽然那个未来从未实现，但三十年后，人们很容易将蓝领工人飞往中国公司工作视为同样命中注定的事情。

In the actual Back to the Future trilogy, the “future” Marty McFly works for a Japanese company in 2015. (His boss, Mr. Fujitsu, fires him by fax.) That movie, the second in the series, was released in 1989, when Hollywood fashionably assumed that your average American would someday be working for Mr. Fujitsu. And although that future never came to pass, it’s tempting, three decades later, to look at blue-collar laborers flying off to work for a Chinese company as equally predestined.

但中国的复苏并非板上钉钉。其他拥有大量廉价劳动力和资源的发展中国家增长速度较慢，而中国基础设施建设热潮本身并不能解释这种差距。中国从危险的毛泽东时代走出来对于这样一个贫穷的国家来说，拥有相对庞大、健康、受过教育的劳动力。邓小平利用这些随时准备开工的公民，宣布中国开放商业，当时全球化的兴起要求中国在世界范围内建立工厂。现在，随着美国转向国内，中国迫切希望再次成为亚洲的主导力量，这是习近平主席的首要任务。

But China’s resurgence was never a lock. Other developing countries with plenty of cheap labor and resources have grown more slowly, and China’s infrastructure binge alone can’t explain the gap. China emerged from its treacherous Maoist period with a relatively large, healthy, literate workforce for such a poor country. Deng Xiaoping leveraged this shovel-ready citizenry by declaring China open for business just as the rise of globalization demanded a factory to the world. Now, with the U.S. pivoting inward, China is eager to level-up once again as the dominant force in Asia, a key priority for President Xi.

自从上台以来，习近平就让中国摆脱了主要关注加强国内经济的方针，并努力通过 《中国的亚洲梦》一书的作者汤姆·米勒所说的“由中国金钱润滑的非正式联盟网络”来建立中国势力范围。从根本上讲，这些联盟是经济联盟，但也是战略联盟，以至于“一带一路”倡议几乎与中国的外交政策密不可分。米勒写道：“北京并不寻求建立正式的联盟结构。”相反，它正在寻求一系列以发展和贸易为支撑的互利地缘战略伙伴关系。

Since coming to power, Xi has moved China away from the dictum that it focus chiefly on strengthening its economy at home and worked to create a Chinese sphere of influence through what Tom Miller, author of China’s Asian Dream, calls “a web of informal alliances lubricated by Chinese cash.” At base, these alliances are economic, but they’re also strategic, to the point that the One Belt One Road initiative has become virtually inseparable from Chinese foreign policy. “Beijing is not seeking to build a formal alliance structure,” writes Miller. Instead, it’s pursuing a range of mutually beneficial geostrategic partnerships buttressed by development and trade.

尽管中国宣称“和平崛起”，但随着中国日益确立其地区大国地位，这些“一带一路”伙伴关系可能会在未来派上用场。中国最明显的姿态出现在南海，但它的存在感在印度洋周边、斯里兰卡、巴基斯坦、东南亚半岛及其他地区都能感受到。一些专家推测，凭借这些海港、机场和工业区，中国正在战略性地在印度洋沿岸打造一条“珍珠链”，未来有一天可以充当海军堡垒，补充并保护其商业利益。然而，到目前为止，还没有确凿的证据来证明这一理论。

Despite claims of a “peaceful rise,” these One Belt One Road partnerships could come in handy down the line as China increasingly asserts itself as a regional power. Its most visible posturing occurs in the South China Sea, but its presence can be felt around the Indian Ocean, in Sri Lanka, Pakistan, down the Southeast Asian peninsula, and beyond. Some experts have theorized that with these seaports, airfields, and industrial zones, China is strategically lacing a “string of pearls” along the rim of the Indian Ocean that can one day act as a naval stronghold to complement—and protect—its commercial interests. So far, however, there’s no smoking gun to prove this theory.

但即使没有建立这样的海军基地，中国也已经从与其他国家的经济“伙伴关系”中获得了地缘战略利益。一个典型的例子就是马来西亚，它是中国投资的主要接受国。马来西亚和中国对南海岛屿的领土主张存在重叠。但与越南和菲律宾等国家相比，马来西亚政府对不满的态度相对温和，称争端应以朋友之间的文明对话方式解决。这可能是明智的做法，因为中国已成为马来西亚最大的外国投资来源之一，更不用说自 2009 年以来一直是其最大的贸易伙伴，两国之间有双边贸易2016 年，中国对马来西亚的投资额超过 500 亿美元。马来西亚的财政账簿最近也出现了赤字。如果中国退出一些重大投资，那么马来西亚——北京喜欢称之为“好伙伴、好邻居”——将陷入相当尴尬的境地。

But even without such naval bases installed, China is already reaping geostrategic benefits from its economic “partnerships” with other countries. A prime example is Malaysia, a major recipient of Chinese investment. Malaysia and China have overlapping territorial claims to islands in the South China Sea. But compared to countries like Vietnam and the Philippines, the Malaysian government has been relatively muted in its grievances, saying the dispute should be resolved as a civil discussion between friends. That’s probably smart, given that China has become one of Malaysia’s biggest sources of foreign investment, not to mention its largest trading partner since 2009, with bilateral trade between the two countries topping $50 billion in 2016. Malaysia’s fiscal ledgers also happen to be awash in red ink these days. If China were to back out of some of its major investments, that would leave Malaysia, its “good partner and good neighbor,” as Beijing likes to call it, in a pretty inconvenient spot.

好伙伴、好邻居

Good Partners and Good Neighbors

马来西亚吉隆坡南部边缘一块占地 486 英亩的土地上，正准备建造一个以高速铁路终点站为核心的新社区。这个综合用途的综合规划区将建在该市已退役的国际机场的停机坪上，该机场最近被马来西亚皇家空军用作基地。拟建开发项目的效果图展示了东南亚城市主义常见的无限城市美学：玻璃摩天大楼、购物中心、绿树环绕的人工湖。这个新区被称为马来西亚城，被誉为“大吉隆坡转型的催化剂”，相当于大规模扩张首都，从头开始建设。

On a 486-acre site on Kuala Lumpur’s southern periphery, Malaysia is preparing to construct a new neighborhood anchored by a high-speed railway terminal. The master-planned, mixed-use district will be built atop the tarmacs of the city’s decommissioned international airport, more recently used as a base by the Royal Malaysian Air Force. Renderings of the proposed development show the familiar infinite-city aesthetic of Southeast Asian urbanism: glass skyscrapers, shopping malls, an artificial lake ringed with greenery. Touted as “the catalyst for the transformation of greater Kuala Lumpur,” Bandar Malaysia, as the new district will be known, amounts to a vast expansion of the capital, to be built from the ground up.

Bandar 的最初概念马来西亚于 2011 年开始成型，有连接吉隆坡其他地区的交通线路，但没有高铁终点站。直到 2013 年，马来西亚和吉隆坡政府才新加坡批准了一项连接两国的高速列车项目。（新加坡将在自己的城市周围建设一个类似的区域）终点站。）2016 年 12 月 13 日，新加坡总理李显龙和马来西亚总理纳吉布拉扎克在签字仪式上正式启动了该项目。全长 217 英里的吉隆坡-新加坡高速铁路 (KLSR) 将横跨马来西亚人口稠密的西海岸，为两座城市之间目前四小时车程的出行提供 90 分钟的替代选择。

The original concept for Bandar Malaysia, which began taking shape in 2011, had transit lines connecting it to the rest of Kuala Lumpur, but no high-speed railway terminal. It wasn’t until 2013 that the governments of Malaysia and Singapore approved a project to link their two countries with a high-speed train. (Singapore will build a similar district around its own terminal.) At a signing ceremony on December 13, 2016, Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak formally launched the project. The 217-mile Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High-Speed Railway (KLSR) will bisect Malaysia’s densely settled west coast, providing a ninety-minute alternative to the current four-hour drive between the two cities.

这条铁路的开通引起了中国的关注。班达尔不再只是宣传材料中所描述的“创意企业中心”，而是为一带一路地图增添另一条交通线路的机会。昆明至新加坡铁路完全由马来西亚和新加坡政府构想和规划，并非像老挝铁路那样由中国推动的项目。但中国无论如何都认为这是在推进其在东南亚的扩张目标。中国官员经常将这条铁路与更大的一带一路计划相提并论，并希望它的建设可以吸引泰国向南修建通往吉隆坡的轨道，使从昆明到新加坡的直达线路更接近现实。

The addition of the train attracted China’s attention. Bandar was no longer simply a “creative enterprise hub,” as its promotional materials describe it, but an opportunity to add another transport link to the One Belt One Road map. Conceived and planned entirely by the governments of Malaysia and Singapore, the KLSR is not a China-propelled project like the railway in Laos. But China sees it as advancing its expansion objectives in Southeast Asia regardless. Chinese officials often mention the railway in the same breath as the larger One Belt One Road initiative, and hope its construction could entice Thailand to build tracks southward to Kuala Lumpur, bringing a contiguous route from Kunming to Singapore another step closer to reality.

至少，吉隆坡高铁为铁路外交提供了一个机会——新加坡和马来西亚正在寻找铁路建设者，中国已经积极竞标该合同。中国在这方面的主要竞争对手是日本，日本是世界上第一列子弹头列车的发源地，也在争夺该项目的合同，该项目价值高达 180 亿美元。据说富裕的新加坡倾向于与日本合作，而马来西亚则倾向于与中国合作，这已经确保马来西亚另一条连接该国东西海岸的铁路合同。

At the very least, the KLSR presents an opportunity for railway diplomacy—Singapore and Malaysia are seeking a builder for the railway, and China has bid aggressively for the contract. China’s chief rival in this regard is Japan, home of the world’s first bullet train, which is also vying for the contract for the project, worth up to $18 billion. Wealthy Singapore was said to favor working with Japan, while Malaysia was leaning toward China, which had already secured the contract for another Malaysian rail link connecting the country’s east and west coasts.

日本曾多次派代表前往吉隆坡进行典型的日本式宣传，强调其在精密工艺和安全方面的声誉，与中国廉价的建设相比，日本是一流的选择。温州郊区发生的高铁事故造成 40 人死亡——部分原因是施工进度仓促——仍然困扰着中国铁路建设的声誉。然而，在中国向马来西亚进行宣传时，在与官员的会谈中，一位中国特使接受了中国惯常的推销策略，他向记者坚称，吉隆坡深水埗铁路“十年的建设时间太长了。五年就足够了”。

Japan has repeatedly sent delegates to Kuala Lumpur to make a characteristically Japanese pitch, emphasizing its reputation for precision craftsmanship and safety, the high-class alternative to China’s cut-rate construction. The high-speed train wreck that killed 40 people in the suburb of Wenzhou—the result, in part, of a rushed construction schedule—still haunts China’s rail-building reputation. And yet, during China’s own pitch to Malaysian officials, a Chinese envoy embraced his country’s usual sales pitch, insisting to a reporter that the KLSR’s “construction timeframe of ten years is too long. Five years would be enough.”

中国官员也采取惯用的策略，不断提醒马来西亚领导人两国是“好伙伴、好邻居”。两国睦邻友好关系可以追溯到 1974 年，当时由纳吉布父亲执政的马来西亚成为第一个与共产主义中国建立外交关系的东盟国家。近年来，两国关系更加密切。2015 年，中国决定在马哈拉施特拉建立外交关系。马来西亚霹雳州是中国在海外的第一家铁路车辆工厂。2015 年，马来西亚所有外国建筑项目总值中，近一半由中国提供。习近平主席将他与纳吉布的关系描述为“有史以来最好的”。

Chinese officials also deployed their go-to tactic of constantly reminding Malaysia’s leaders of their countries’ “friendly relations” as “good partners and good neighbors.” The neighborliness dates to 1974 when Malaysia, then run by Najib’s father, became the first ASEAN country to establish diplomatic ties with communist China. In recent years, the two nations have grown even closer. In 2015, China decided to locate its first overseas railcar factory in Malaysia’s Perak State. Nearly half the value of all foreign construction projects in Malaysia was provided by China in 2015. President Xi has characterized his relationship with Najib as the “best ever.”

这项善意基础为中国迄今最大的举动之一奠定了基础，此举将立即改变 KLSR 合同的竞争格局。2015 年 12 月，中国铁路工程总公司 (CREC) 与一家马来西亚房地产开发商，同意以 17 亿美元收购马来西亚城 60% 的股份。事实上，CREC 不仅会收购这个大型房地产开发项目，它将向该地产再投入 20 亿美元，在那里设立其东南亚总部。

This goodwill groundwork set the stage for one of China’s biggest gestures yet, one that would instantly reconfigure the race for the KLSR contract. In December 2015, China Railway Engineering Corp. (CREC), partnering with a Malaysia-based real estate developer, agreed to buy a 60 percent stake in Bandar Malaysia for $1.7 billion. In fact, not only would CREC buy into the massive real estate development, it would pour another $2 billion into the property to establish its Southeast Asian headquarters there.

对于担心中国人口饱和的马来西亚人来说，这则消息就像一场空袭警报响起。“马来西亚城已成为中国城”，一个博客的头条新闻如此写道。马来西亚一下子将其最大的房地产项目的控制权拱手让给了一个外国势力，并将这种势力推向了马来西亚政府坚称，由于购买财团包括一家马来西亚开发商，马来西亚城在技术上仍由马来西亚控股。但更简单的故事仍然适用：中国在 2009 年超越新加坡成为马来西亚最大的贸易伙伴，也超越这个岛国成为马来西亚房地产的最大投资者。

For Malaysians leery of Chinese saturation, the news went off like an air raid siren. “Bandar Malaysia Has Become Bandar China,” blared the headline atop one blog. In one fell swoop, Malaysia had abdicated control of its biggest real estate venture to a foreign power and launched that power to the top of its foreign investor list. The government insisted that because the buying consortium included a Malaysia-based developer, Bandar Malaysia was still technically a majority-Malaysian holding. But the simpler story stuck: China, having eclipsed Singapore as Malaysia’s top trading partner in 2009, had outstripped the island city-state as the biggest investor in Malaysian property, too.

在一个对中国财富的不满情绪暗流涌动的国家，仅凭这种情况下，这笔交易本身就足以引起人们的不满。但据称出售的动机更是雪上加霜。当时，纳吉布政府因一桩政治丑闻而受到媒体的猛烈抨击，这起丑闻源于 1MDB，这是纳吉布于 2009 年设立的国有投资基金，旨在资助一系列经济发展项目，以促进马来西亚经济。但据调查人员称，1MDB 只不过是一箱零花钱，总理的同伙们可以从中动用这些零花钱来实现他们最疯狂的梦想。高达 40 亿美元的资金据称，这些钱被挪用到一些人身上，这些人把钱花在了从公司飞机到洛杉矶豪宅的一切东西上。瑞士总检察长称这是一个庞氏骗局。

In a country where resentment of Chinese wealth simmers just below the surface, the optics of the deal would have ruffled feathers under these circumstances alone. But the alleged motive for the sale was salt in the wound. At the time, Najib’s administration was being hammered in the press for a political scandal that stemmed from 1MDB, a state-owned investment fund put in place by Najib in 2009 to fund a range of economic development projects to boost the Malaysian economy. But according to investigators, 1MDB became little more than a box of petty cash that associates of the prime minister could dip into to fund their wildest dreams. Upward of $4 billion was allegedly misappropriated to people who blew it on everything from corporate jets to lavish Los Angeles mansions. The Swiss attorney general called it a ponzi scheme.

到 2016 年中，1MDB 成为美国司法部诉讼的对象，并成为多个国家展开多项调查的目标。据美国司法部长称，美国“最大的盗贼统治案件”历史。纳吉本人被指控收受了近 7 亿美元，但他否认了这一指控。通过资产清算计划，政府迅速偿还 1MDB 的巨额债务。出售马来西亚城是这一努力的关键部分。

By the middle of 2016, 1MDB was the subject of a U.S. Department of Justice lawsuit, the target of multiple investigations across several countries, and according to the U.S. attorney general, the “largest kleptocracy case” in American history. Najib himself was accused of receiving nearly $700 million, a charge he denied. Through an asset liquidation program, the government raced to draw down 1MDB’s enormous debt. The sell-off of Bandar Malaysia was a crucial part of this effort.

班达尔交易是总理陷入赤字、负面报道和诉讼的救命稻草。《 海峡时报》 直接将此事称为出售是中国的“救助”，但无论这是一份及时的礼物还是一项审慎的投资都无关紧要。无论如何，它都让 KLSR 感受到了中国慷慨的光芒。突然间，把建造合同授予日本的想法似乎非常不知感恩。“我们正双手双脚投入战斗“被捆绑了。”一位日本高管绝望地说道。

The Bandar deal was a lifeline for a prime minister drowning in red ink, bad press, and litigation. The Straits Times went right ahead and branded the sale a Chinese “bailout,” but whether it was a well-timed gift or a prudent investment was beside the point. Either way, it had the effect of infusing the KLSR with the glow of Chinese generosity. Suddenly the idea of awarding Japan the contract to build it seemed awfully ungrateful. “We are entering the fight with both hands tied,” despaired a Japanese executive.

然而，这一切在 2017 年 5 月 3 日发生了变化，当时马来西亚财政部突然取消了向中国财团出售马来西亚城股权的交易。财政部在一份简短的声明中宣布，该协议一经达成就已胎死腹中，并指责买家声称合同被取消是因为他们“未能履行付款义务”。

That all changed on May 3, 2017, however, when Malaysia’s Ministry of Finance abruptly called off the deal to sell the Bandar Malaysia stake to the Chinese consortium. In a terse announcement, the ministry declared the agreement dead on arrival and blamed the buyers, claiming the contract was canceled because they had “failed to meet the payment obligations.”

该财团对此提出异议，称其“没有充分、准确地反映情况”。但该部的解释被许多观察人士接受，认为似乎有道理。四个月前，中国央行宣布其外汇储备当时，人民币汇率已跌破 3 万亿美元，这是一个非官方的恐慌区。这引发了一系列资本管制，限制了人民币流出该国和流入外国大型项目的金额。在这种管制下，吉隆坡一座耗资 17 亿美元的火车站（以及即将耗资 20 亿美元的总部）是北京可能会选择推迟的那种奢侈品收购。

The consortium disputed this, countering that it didn’t “fully and accurately reflect the circumstances.” But the ministry’s explanation was accepted by many observers as plausible. Four months earlier, China’s central bank had declared that its foreign exchange reserves had dipped below $3 trillion, an unofficial panic zone. This triggered a series of capital controls that reined in how much renminbi could flow out of the country and into foreign megaprojects. Under the clampdown, a $1.7 billion train station in Kuala Lumpur—with a $2 billion headquarters to come—was the kind of luxury purchase Beijing might choose to postpone.

其他人猜测，自从谈判开始以来，班达尔的土地价值已经飙升，促使马来西亚退出，希望找到更好的交易。或者，纳吉布终于被指责为中国的走狗，他觉得有必要撰写一篇辩护性专栏文章称，他“不会为想要为马来西亚建设世界一流的基础设施而道歉”。

Others speculated that the land for Bandar had ballooned in value since negotiations began, prompting Malaysia to back out in hopes of finding a better deal. Or perhaps the accusations that he was China’s lapdog had finally gotten to Najib, who felt the need to pen a defensive op-ed saying he would “make no apologies for wanting to build world-class infrastructure for Malaysia.”

“这不是一次性的事情，”曾在 2009 年至 2011 年担任纳吉布政治秘书的吴逸山说。“这个位置非常有吸引力。如果这笔交易没有成功，他们可以找到另一个买家，来自中国或其他地方。”在与中国的班达尔交易破裂后不久，日本国土交通省部长回到吉隆坡和新加坡，大谈日本的列车技术并宣布再次推动“涉及融资、人才培养和与本地企业合作的具体提案”。

“It’s not as if this was a one-shot thing,” says Oh Ei Sun, who served as Najib’s political secretary from 2009 to 2011. “The location is extremely attractive. If this deal doesn’t go through, they can get another buyer, from China or elsewhere.” Shortly after the Bandar deal with China collapsed, the Japanese Minister of Land, Infrastructure, Transport, and Tourism was back in Kuala Lumpur and Singapore, talking up Japanese train technology and announcing a fresh push “for a specific proposal involving financing, talent development, and collaboration with local companies.”

中国可能会卷土重来，拿出一份新的提案，重新赢得马来西亚城和高铁本身的合同。但如果它如果不这样做，还有其他选择。“中国通常有非常模糊的最终目标，”吴逸山说。一带一路就是这样，其既定目标既模糊又多样：促进连通性、加强贸易关系、控制供应链、投资海外——这些目标在设计上可以通过多种方式实现。正是这种流动性让一些中国海外企业拥有了梦幻般的超现实感：通向虚无的悬索桥和被遗弃在沙漠中的工厂城镇。

China could stage a triumphant comeback, returning with a fresh proposal that wins it the contract anew for Bandar Malaysia and for the high-speed railway itself. But if it doesn’t, there are other options. “China generally has very vague end goals,” says Oh Ei Sun. That’s certainly the case with One Belt One Road, the stated aims of which are as nebulous as they are varied: promote connectivity, strengthen trade relations, control supply chains, invest abroad—goals that, by design, can be reached in any number of ways. It’s this fluidity that gives some Chinese foreign ventures their hallucinatory surreality: soaring suspension bridges to nowhere and factory towns marooned in the desert.

其中一个项目位于马来西亚海岸附近的平静水域，距离吉隆坡南海铁路驶入新加坡前的最后一站只有几步之遥。在柔佛海峡（马来西亚和新加坡之间的狭长水域）的一连串人工岛屿上，中国正在建造一座城市。截至撰写本文时，这是一条用聚乙烯薄膜包裹的半成品高楼天际线。任何想买公寓的人都可以四处逛逛，因此，我和一位新加坡朋友在五月的一个炎热的星期天穿过新柔长堤前往那里。

One of these ventures can be found in the placid waters just off the Malaysian coast, spitting distance from the KLSR’s final scheduled stop before it pulls into Singapore. On a string of manmade islands in the Johor Strait, the narrow strip of water that separates Malaysia from Singapore, China is building a city. As of this writing, it’s a skyline of half-finished towers wrapped in polyethylene sheeting. Anyone looking to buy a condo is welcome to poke around, so a Singaporean friend and I took a trip across the Johor-Singapore Causeway on a scorching Sunday in May.

和磨丁和马来西亚城一样，中国的城市是 21 世纪土地使用逻辑的产物，其中城市化可以部分脱离国家领土主张。通过合作增加马来西亚最南端海岸的密度，马来西亚和中国希望吸收相邻新加坡经济的热能。与此同时，新加坡将新开发视为其拥有自己的边界——狭小岛屿居民可以投资和定居的客房。这是又一个协同共赢的一带一路特色。新加坡将提供繁荣，中国正在建设城市。马来西亚只是踢开土地而已。

As with Boten and Bandar Malaysia, China’s city is the product of a twenty-first-century land-use logic in which urbanism can be partially divorced from claims of national territory. By working together to densify Malaysia’s southernmost shores, Malaysia and China hope to absorb the thermal energy of adjacent Singapore’s economy. Singapore, meanwhile, views the new development as an extension of its own borders—a guest bedroom that its cramped island residents can invest in and settle into. It’s yet another synergistic, win-win One Belt One Road special. Singapore will provide the prosperity, and China is building the city. Malaysia simply kicked in the land.

绝对和平的圣地

A Sanctuary of Utter Peace

森林城市​​是中国开发的一项可容纳 70 万居民的开发项目，建在马来西亚海岸附近的一系列人工岛屿上。由于横跨柔佛海峡的桥梁直接连接马来西亚和新加坡（1965 年之前，两国都是一个整体），这项耗资 1000 亿美元的开发项目主要被宣传为毗邻新加坡。宣传材料称其为“全球商业和文化集群”，好像它根本不效忠任何国家，并指出新的轻轨系统将把它连接到附近的吉隆坡轻轨。

Forest City is a Chinese development with room for 700,000 residents being built across a string of manmade islands just off the coast of Malaysia. Since bridges spanning the Johor Strait directly connect Malaysia and Singapore—they were a single entity until 1965—the $100 billion development is marketed chiefly as Singapore-adjacent. Promotional materials call it a “global cluster of commerce and culture,” as if it pledges allegiance to no country at all, and note that a new light rail system will connect it to the nearby KLSR.

在销售展厅里，这座城市的庞大规模通过其炫目的比例模型得以展示，模型本身几乎大到足以让一个孩子像一只掠夺成性的哥斯拉一样笨拙地穿过。模型的扭曲银色公寓大楼散布着空中花园和紫色 LED 灯，营造出一种时髦的月球殖民地氛围。几栋大楼的正面都挂着“已售罄”的标志。

In the sales showroom, the city’s sheer size was on display in its glitzy scale model, which itself was nearly big enough for a child to lumber through like a marauding Godzilla. The model’s twisty silver condo towers were strewn with hanging gardens and purple LED lights, lending it a hip moon colony vibe. Several had SOLD OUT signs hanging across their facades.

我跟着一位名叫 Fancy 的销售助理参观了三室和四室的样板房。Fancy 来自中国广东省，身着复古时尚的 卡巴雅服饰。高背扶手椅、镶有宝石的靠垫、全套厨具，什么都逃不过她的激光笔。落地窗俯瞰着电蓝色的大海。客厅壁挂式电视上播放着一段宣传视频，视频中中国夫妇说：“这里住着许多华裔。对我们来说，这更像是住在家乡，而不是在国外。”

I rubbernecked my way through three- and four-bedroom model apartments at the heel of a sales associate named Fancy. Fancy was from China’s Guangdong Province and outfitted in a retro-trendy kebaya. Nothing escaped her laser pen: high-backed armchairs, bejeweled throw pillows, all-clad kitchenware. Floor to ceiling windows overlooked an electric-blue sea. On a living room’s wall-mounted TV, a promotional video featured Chinese couples saying things like, “Many ethnic Chinese live here. For us, it’s more like we’re living in our hometown than a foreign country.”

森林城市​​的宣传语概括起来就是：住在中国，但在新加坡……在马来西亚。正如一位在东南亚工作的美国企业主告诉我的那样，“有很多中国人不想住在中国，但他们仍然想住在‘中国’。”森林城市就像一位来自工业重镇杭州的退休人员向《 亚洲时报》热情地评论道，杭州“就像一座唐人街” ，她解释了为什么她要在这里购买一栋平房。

This is Forest City’s pitch in a nutshell: Live in China, but in Singapore . . . in Malaysia. As an American business owner working in Southeast Asia told me, “There are a lot of Chinese who don’t want to live in China, but they still want to live in ‘China.’” Forest City is “like a Chinatown,” as one retiree from the gritty factory city of Hangzhou brightly remarked to the Asia Times, explaining why she’d purchased a bungalow there.

从一开始，森林城市的目标市场就是千里之外的居民，比如天津和广州等交通拥堵、雾霾严重的中国城市。建设森林城市的中国开发商碧桂园在当地媒体市场购买了播出时间，直接向逃避现实的中国买家推销其“靠近新加坡”的公寓。

From the start, Forest City’s target market has been residents of places thousands of miles away—congested, smoggy Chinese cities like Tianjin and Guangzhou, where Country Garden, the China-based developer building Forest City, has bought airtime in local media markets and pitched its “near Singapore” condos directly to escapist Chinese buyers.

马来西亚过去曾接纳过大量中国移民。19 世纪中叶，克里米亚战争和美国内战导致士兵对罐头食品的需求飙升。马来西亚有一些马来西亚是世界上最大的锡矿产地之一，因此该国邀请中国劳工来开采锡矿。到 19 世纪末，马来西亚的锡矿供应量占全球的一半。多年来，成千上万的中国工人永久定居在马来西亚，成为餐馆老板、鸦片馆老板和罐头大亨。如今，华人是该国第二大族群，尽管政府不愿给予新移民完全公民权。

Malaysia has accommodated inflows of Chinese immigrants in the past. In the middle of the nineteenth century, soldiers fighting in the Crimean War and the American Civil War sent demand for canned foods soaring. Malaysia had some of the world’s largest tin deposits, and the country invited Chinese laborers in to excavate its tin mines. By the late 1800s, it was the source of half the global tin supply. Over the years, thousands of these Chinese workers settled in Malaysia permanently, becoming restaurateurs, opium den proprietors, and canning tycoons. Today, Chinese is the second-largest ethnic group in the country, though the government is loathe to grant full citizenship to new arrivals.

相反，它创建了独一无二的慷慨的马来西亚第二家园签证 (MM2H)，允许拥有足够可支配收入的外籍人士几乎无限制地入境，但不提供公民身份。MM2H 使马来西亚成为世界上最容易移民的国家之一。有效期为十年，续签也轻而易举，它实际上是永久居留权的通行证。它的主要要求是拥有一个约 120,000 美元流动现金的银行账户和每月约 2,500 美元的海外收入，这是终身居留的低门槛。2016年，44%的签证成功申请者是中国人。

Instead, it created the uniquely generous Malaysia My Second Home visa (MM2H), which grants nearly unlimited entry to expats with sufficient disposable income, short of providing citizenship. MM2H has made Malaysia one of the easiest nations on earth to move to. Good for ten years and a breeze to renew, it’s effectively a pass for permanent residency. Its main requirements are a bank account with about $120,000 in liquid cash and a monthly offshore income of approximately $2,500, a low bar to clear for a lifelong stay. In 2016, 44 percent of the visa’s successful applicants were Chinese.

森林城市​​是马来西亚依斯干达特区的一部分，依斯干达特区是一条经济增长走廊，紧邻马来西亚海岸，与新加坡隔海相望。该走廊大致模仿了中国著名的经济特区深圳，其发展计划旨在让到2025年，它将发展成为“一个强大且可持续发展的、具有国际地位的大都市”。

Forest City is one small part of Iskandar Malaysia, an economic growth corridor that hugs the Malaysian coast just across the water from Singapore. The corridor is roughly modeled on Shenzhen, the celebrated Chinese special economic zone, with a development plan that aims to make it “a strong and sustainable metropolis of international standing” by 2025.

无论与深圳的比较是否恰当，中国都对伊斯干达产生了浓厚的兴趣，其海岸沿线建有大批经济实惠的豪华公寓大楼。如果森林城市范西说，如果这不适合我们，她可以建议我们去金海湾，这是一条路上的“综合海滨生活”城市，距离新加坡大桥只有四英里。还有公主湾，面积是金海湾的三倍，还有许多类似的中国建造的开发项目，目前处于不同的完工阶段。

Whether the Shenzhen comparison fits, China has taken a shine to Iskandar, lining its shores with swarms of affordable-luxury condominium towers. If Forest City didn’t suit us, Fancy said, might she suggest Danga Bay, an “integrated waterfront living” city up the road, a brisk four miles from the bridge to Singapore. There’s also Princess Cove, three times the size of Danga Bay, and a multitude of similar Chinese-built developments in various stages of completion.

这些建在海上人工岛屿上的水晶城堡，令人忍俊不禁——它们闪闪发光的靠垫、暴发户的名字、宣传册上承诺的“绝对和平的避难所”。但看到满怀希望的年轻家庭在森林城市的样板公寓里闲逛，看到情侣在白色沙滩上自拍，而他们的孩子在喷雾机游乐场上疯狂奔跑，我不禁想到，正如国泰航空的机上广告所说，对于那些想要接触一带一路机遇的人来说，这是一个理想的选择。如果说一带一路是让国家边界更加开放的一项努力，那么像森林城市这样的地方，加上马来西亚第二家园签证等手段，就是实现这一目标的可靠手段——为特定类型的亚洲外籍人士提供经济上可行的居住安排。

It’s tempting to smirk at these crystal castles set atop artificial islands in the sea—their bedazzled throw pillows, their nouveau riche names, their brochures promising “a sanctuary of utter peace.” But watching hopeful young families poke around the model apartments at Forest City, seeing couples take selfies on the white-sand beach while their kids ran amok in the mist-machine playground, I couldn’t help but think that this was an ideal setup for people who were, as the Cathay Pacific in-flight advertisement put it, connecting to One Belt One Road opportunities. If One Belt One Road is an effort to make national borders more permeable, places like Forest City, aided by devices like the MM2H visa, are a credible means to that end—financially feasible living arrangements for a particular brand of Asian expat.

这提醒我们，一带一路就像中国的“走出去”战略一样，是要求中国人在全球各地进行创业和投机性房地产投资的命令。理想情况下，所有这些分子企业都凝聚成经济生态系统，就像 70 年前美国的基础设施建设闪电战帮助欧洲实现的那样。在马歇尔计划的众多目标中，名列前茅的是确保欧洲稳定，并有足够的资金来吸收战后美国剩余的出口过剩。现在中国也有类似的过剩，而且类似的目标：将东南亚城市中心之间沉睡的、无精打采、朦胧的潮湿农田城市化。

It’s a reminder that One Belt One Road, like China’s “Go Out” strategy, is a diktat to the Chinese people to barnstorm the world with entrepreneurial ventures and speculative real estate. Ideally, all these molecular enterprises congeal into economic ecosystems, just as America’s infrastructural blitz helped happen in Europe seventy years ago. Of the Marshall Plan’s many ambitions, high on the list was ensuring that Europe was stable and moneyed enough to siphon off postwar America’s residual export glut. Now China has a similar glut, and a similar goal: to urbanize the listless, hazy stretches of soggy farmland that slumber between Southeast Asia’s urban cores.

不难想象，森林城市模板将以惊人的效率沿着铁路沿线复制，了解该项目的人相信这会发生。亚洲逆向工程了城市化的艺术，整个城市都是从零开始建造的，然后在空调销售展厅里逐个出售。

It’s not hard to imagine the Forest City template cloned with overhead-shearing efficiency along the railway’s route, as those with knowledge of the project believe will happen. Asia has reverse-engineered the art of urbanization, in which entire cities are constructed from scratch and sold unit by unit in air-conditioned sales showrooms.

“挑战在于，当高铁抵达这些地方的中心时，政府规划人员如何利用它将这些地区变成社区？”领导设计马来西亚城的建筑师团队的艾德·贝克说。他用红色记号笔在白板上画了一条略带波浪的垂直线，并用点点缀。“高铁的一些站点位于甘榜 ” ——一种马来西亚村庄，里面有高架隔板房屋，顶部是波纹铁皮屋顶。“这是一个浪漫的村庄。人们住在带有小花园的小房子里。”

“The challenge will be, when the high-speed rail arrives in the middle of these places, how do the government planners use it to turn those areas into communities?” says Ed Baker, who led the team of architects that designed Bandar Malaysia. With red marker, he draws a slightly wavy vertical line on a whiteboard, punctuating it with dots. “Some of these stops on the high-speed rail, the stations are in a kampong”—a Malaysian village with stilt-raised clapboard houses topped with roofs of corrugated tin. “It’s a village in the romantic sense. People live in little houses with little gardens.”

例如，芙蓉市的高铁站不会设在芙蓉市区，而是设在芙蓉以西十英里的寂静的拉布，这是一片林木茂密、遍布乡村道路和棕榈油厂的地区。随着高铁站的临近，房地产开发商已经报告了土地价值的上涨，这些地区的人口密度和社区对开发的抵制情绪可能都很低。“你会发现很多私人开发商对这些 甘榜很感兴趣，”贝克说。“有人可能会说，‘我要用两千公顷土地建一个办公园区，我要把它叫做‘高速城’。’”

The high-speed rail station for the city of Seremban, for instance, won’t be in Seremban proper, but ten miles west in sleepy Labu, a wooded enclave of country roads and palm oil mills. With a high-speed railway station looming, property developers have already reported a rise in land values, where both density and community resistance to development are likely to be low. “You’ll find a lot of private developers are interested in these kampongs,” says Baker. “One might say, ‘I’m going to take two thousand hectares and build an office park and I’m going to call it High-Speed City.’”

马来西亚前总理马哈蒂尔·穆罕默德已成为“马来西亚优先”选区事实上的代言人，他经常对所有这些由中国支持的发展项目发出警告。他有一个脾气暴躁的博客，直言不讳地表示，他对“许多最有价值的土地现在将被外国人拥有和占领”的想法感到担忧。他写道，实际上，这些发展“将成为外国土地”。

Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysia’s former prime minister, has emerged as the de facto voice of the “Malaysia First” constituency, issuing frequent warnings about all this Chinesebacked development. Armed with an ornery blog, he’s been outspoken in his alarm over the idea that “much of the most valuable land will now be owned and occupied by foreigners.” In effect, he writes, these developments “will become foreign land.”

如果说中国开发商热衷于涉足这一领域，那么数百万中国个人也同样如此，他们将这些项目视为个人获利的机会，而不是中国国营经济的兴奋剂。在所有创造财富的工具中，交通基础设施是历史上最受欢迎的。两个世纪前，佐治亚州在地上立了一个里程标桩。它成为了西部和大西洋铁路的东部终点站。围绕它兴起的城市最初被称为终点站，现在被称为亚特兰大。它是由涌向那里以分一杯羹的泥瓦匠、煤气工人、银行家和机械师建造的。

If Chinese developers are eager to dive in, so are millions of individual Chinese, who see these projects not as steroids for China’s state-run economy, but as opportunities for personal gain. Of all the tools for generating wealth, transportation infrastructure is history’s favorite. Two centuries ago the State of Georgia stuck a mile marker post in the ground. It became the eastern terminus of the Western and Atlantic Railroad. The city that sprung up around it was originally called Terminus, and is now called Atlanta. It was built by the bricklayers, gas workers, bankers, and machinists who flocked there for a piece of the transit-oriented action.

如今在东南亚，铁路沿线出现的大理石酒店、翻斗车经销店、麻婆豆腐店、玉器商场，构成了“借助铁路顺风蓬勃发展的各种中小型项目”。人类学家克里斯·利特尔顿称这些项目为“巨型项目”。它们是数百万中国移民沿着中国修建的铁路、公路、机场和海港进入沙漠和丛林，并在途中开店的产物。

Today in Southeast Asia, the marbled hotels, dump truck dealerships, mapo tofu joints, and jade emporiums appearing along the railway’s route make up the “variety of meso- and mini-projects [that] thrive on the tailwinds of the megaprojects,” as the anthropologist Chris Lyttleton calls them. They’re the product of millions of Chinese migrants following China-built railways, highways, airports, and seaports into the deserts and jungles, setting up shop as they go.

习近平主席最近在与省级领导和政府相关首席执行官交谈时，经常引用一句中国谚语： 要想致富，先修路。 道路本身并不能带来投资回报，而选择走这条路的人才是真正的投资回报。无论一带一路位于哪个国家，其基础设施的存在，在一定程度上是为了海外 华人——即“海外华人”——将他们的个人生活抱负与北京的长期宏观经济战略同步。

President Xi has lately been apt to quote a particular Chinese proverb when speaking to provincial leaders and state-linked CEOs: If you want to get rich, first build a road. It’s not the road itself that offers a return on investment, but the people who choose to follow it. The infrastructure of One Belt One Road, no matter what country it’s in, exists, in part, for the haiwai huaren—the “overseas Chinese”—syncing their personal life ambitions with Beijing’s long-term macroeconomic strategies.

在森林城市，我不知道 海外华人都去哪儿 了。我到达时以为会有大量来自无锡和南京等城市的买家。但我发现，大部分都是马来西亚家庭，妇女们戴着头巾遮挡旱季的阳光，还有衣着考究的新加坡投资者在询问转租政策。

In Forest City, I wondered where all the haiwai huaren were. I arrived expecting planeloads of buyers from cities like Wuxi and Nanjing. What I found instead were mostly Malaysian families, the women shielding themselves from the dry-season sun with their hijabs, and sharply dressed Singaporean investors inquiring about subletting policies.

2016 年，中国买家抢占了海外房地产投资增长 330 亿美元，比上年增长 53%。但资本管制可能将中国赶出马来西亚城，而伊斯干达海滨公寓市场也受到了同样的打击。由于对外汇储备感到恐慌，北京指示在海外购买房地产的中国公民将资金留在国内，这震动了从奥克兰到洛杉矶的房地产市场

In 2016, Chinese buyers scooped up $33 billion in offshore real estate, a 53 percent increase from the year before. But the same capital controls that may have blasted China out of Bandar Malaysia had strafed the Iskandar waterfront condominium market as well. Panicked about its currency reserves, Beijing instructed Chinese citizens buying real estate abroad to keep their money at home instead, shaking property markets from Auckland to L.A.

突然之间，已经支付了 10% 首付的未来森林城市居民被派往香港和澳门继续支付分期付款。由于森林城市在大陆的销售办事处中国关闭“用于装修”，新客户开始在新加坡、雅加达和吉隆坡寻找新客户。在上海银行的移动应用程序上，弹出警告，提醒用户如果计划使用外汇购买中国境外的房产，不要购买外汇。

Suddenly, future Forest City residents who had already forked over 10 percent down payments were being sent to Hong Kong and Macau to continue paying their installments. As Forest City’s sales offices in mainland China closed “for renovations,” new ones began seeking out new clientele in Singapore, Jakarta, and Kuala Lumpur. On the Bank of Shanghai’s mobile app, a pop-up warning cautioned users not to buy foreign exchange if they planned to use it to purchase property outside of China.

争论很快转向森林城市是否会成为中国臭名昭著的鬼城之一。森林城市刚刚交付了首批 132 套公寓的钥匙。这些鬼城是为一百万未到场的买家精心规划和建造的，它们已经成为无法抗拒的隐喻，是渴望证明中国存在缺陷的西方观众眼中的堤坝裂缝。

Debate quickly turned to whether Forest City, which had just handed over the keys to its first 132 apartments, would become one of China’s infamous ghost cities. Meticulously planned and constructed for a million no-show buyers, these ghost cities have become irresistible metaphors, cracks in the dyke for Western audiences eager for proof of Chinese fallibility.

最早声名狼藉的鬼城之一是鄂尔多斯康巴什，它于 2003 年在中国内蒙古自治区高原破土动工。英国广播公司 2012 年的一篇文章引用了这座几乎空无一人的城市作为“中国伟大的建筑热潮……已经结束”的证据。然而，韦德·谢泼德在其著作 《中国的鬼城》中认为，这种赞美为时过早，他指出，许多城市的规划都是在 20 年内填满人口，期待它们一夜之间人口爆满是对中国城市化模式的误解——中国的城市化模式是城市产生人口，而不是人口产生城市。

One of the earliest ghost cities to rise to infamy was Ordos Kangbashi, which broke ground in 2003 on the plateau of Inner Mongolia, an autonomous region of China. A visit from the BBC in 2012 cited the mostly vacant city as proof “that the great Chinese building boom . . . is over.” In his book Ghost Cities of China, however, Wade Shepard argues this eulogy is premature, pointing out that many of these cities are designed to fill up on twenty-year timelines, and that expecting them to populate overnight is a failure to understand China’s model of urbanization—one in which the city generates population, rather than the other way around.

谢泼德最近回到了鄂尔多斯康巴什，发现那里“人口众多”，这要归功于中国当局积极的社会工程。2006 年，当地政府的行政首府从 20 英里外的另一个城市东胜迁到了那里。据《 纽约时报》报道，时刻表、公交线路据称，当时两地之间的公路被关闭，迫使政府官员搬到康巴什办公地点附近。理想的学校也迁往康巴什。瞧，一座可容纳 30 万居民的城市已经住满了三分之一。谢泼德指出，中国政府有多种手段可以吸引公民迁入新城市，“就像军事指挥官在战场上调遣部队一样，在全国各地调动人口，”他写道。

Shepard recently returned to Ordos Kangbashi and found “a substantial population there,” thanks to aggressive social engineering on the part of the Chinese authorities. In 2006, the administrative capital of the local government was relocated there from Dongsheng, another urban area twenty miles away. According to the New York Times, bus service between the two areas was then allegedly shut down, forcing government officials to move near their offices in Kangbashi. Desirable schools were relocated to Kangbashi. Lo and behold, a city with space for 300,000 residents had become one-third full. As Shepard points out, the Chinese government has a multitude of tools that it can use to entice citizens into new cities, “shifting the population around the country as a military commander maneuvers troops on a battlefield,” he writes.

“一带一路”旨在将中国在城市化和高铁方面的成功经验复制到世界其他国家。但在森林城市和其他中国海外开发项目中，中国在国内取得成功的许多应对措施将无法应用。离开森林城市时，范西在门口拦住我，不是要进行最后的强行推销，而只是为了确保我的短暂访问愉快。然后，她在一本精美的小册子上写下了她的 Whatsapp 号码，递给了我。“当你准备好在森林城市购买房产时，请告诉我，”她微笑着说，“或者在我们其他社区购买。”

One Belt One Road aims to replicate China’s domestic successes in urbanization and high-speed rail in other countries around the world. But in Forest City and other offshore Chinese developments, many of the countermeasures China has used to create success at home won’t be available. As we were leaving Forest City, Fancy stopped me at the door, not to deliver a final hard sell, but simply to make sure my short visit had been a pleasant one. Then she wrote her Whatsapp number on a glossy brochure and handed it to me. “Let me know when you’re ready to purchase your property at Forest City,” she smiled, “or at any of our other communities.”

有限服务

Limited Service

2011 年，泰国被评为中上收入国家，世界银行称赞其为“最伟大的发展成功案例之一”。政变和洪水都未能击垮“特氟龙泰国”的经济滑行道，自 1970 年代泰国开放经济以来，泰国经济一直与中国紧密相连。邓小平推行中国经济自由化政策时，泰国最大的私营企业之一正大集团是第一家走进中国大门的境外企业。（其在深圳经济特区投资证书上的外国注册号码为“0001”。）两国于 1975 年建立外交关系，并通过互惠互利的经济优惠政策加强了这种关系，例如中国向泰国分销商出售燃油可享受“友谊价”，开启了持续至今的强劲贸易关系时代。

In 2011, Thailand was anointed an upper-middle income country, earning it a World Bank shout-out as “one of the great development success stories.” Coups and floods failed to knock “Teflon Thailand” off this economic glidepath, which has been closely tethered to China’s since that country opened for business in the 1970s. When Deng Xiaoping liberalized China’s economy, one of Thailand’s biggest private companies, Charoen Pokphand, was the first offshore enterprise to walk through the door. (Its foreign registration number on its Shenzhen SEZ investment certificate is “0001.”) The countries established diplomatic ties in 1975, and bolstered these ties with mutually lucrative economic perks—like “friendship prices” for Chinese fuel sold to Thai distributors—launching an era of robust trade relations that continues to this day.

自此以后，两国关系日益密切。2010 年，中国超越美国，成为泰国最大的贸易伙伴。最大的出口市场。两年后，它取代日本成为泰国最大的贸易伙伴。一项自由贸易协定取消了 200 多种水果和蔬菜的关税，泰国农产品出口激增，出口到痴迷于菠萝蜜和榴莲的中国消费者。反过来，中国也让数以百万计的游客飞往泰国的海滩和妓院，使两国之间的空中交通量翻了一番，使得曼谷成为世界上游客最多的城市。

Since then, the two countries have only grown closer. In 2010, China surpassed the U.S. to become Thailand’s largest export market. Two years later, it replaced Japan as Thailand’s biggest trading partner. A free trade agreement zeroed out tariffs on over two hundred fruits and vegetables, spiking Thai agricultural exports to jackfruit- and durian-obsessed Chinese consumers. China, in turn, has flown millions upon millions of tourists to Thai beaches and brothels, doubling country-to-country air traffic and making Bangkok the most visited city on earth.

2013 年，中国国务院总理李克强飞往曼谷，与时任泰国总理英拉·西那瓦共同公开揭幕高铁展览。中国媒体报道说，这是一场奠基仪式，但实际上并非如此。李克强称这条尚不存在的铁路是“双边关系的新亮点”。

In 2013, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang flew to Bangkok to publicly inaugurate a high-speed train exhibition with Thailand’s then-Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra. The Chinese press covered the event as if it were a ceremonial groundbreaking, even though it was no such thing. Li called the not-yet-existent railway “a new highlight in bilateral relations.”

但七个月后，英拉被安置在曼谷北部的一个军营，接受武装监视，而巴育·占奥差将军则坐在了总理的位子上。

But seven months later, Yingluck was under armed supervision at an army camp north of Bangkok, and General Prayuth Chan-ocha was sitting in the prime minister’s chair.

泰国政权更迭令北京感到沮丧。每次新政府上台，项目谈判都必须重新开始，而军政府将该国的主要基础设施项目搁置，等待进一步审查。直到 2015 年 1 月，军政府才为该计划注入了新的活力。巴育宣布铁路将于 9 月破土动工，火车车厢将在两年半内投入运行。但到了 9 月，与中国的谈判并没有达成泰国人可以接受的条件。

Thailand’s regime changes are a source of frustration for Beijing. Negotiations on projects must restart with each new incoming administration, and the junta put the country’s major infrastructure projects on hold pending further review. Not until January 2015 did the military government breathe new life into the scheme. Prayuth announced the railway would break ground by September and that train cars would roll within two-and-a-half years. But when September arrived, talks with China had not produced terms the Thais could live with.

12 月，《 曼谷邮报》 报道称，建设将于明年 5 月“按计划”开始。“曼谷将成为中国的铁路枢纽，”标题写道。（不是泰国的铁路枢纽，而是中国的。）同样，重要的日子来了又去。十几次双边会议都未能解决资金、贷款条件和分工问题。曼谷法政大学国际商务、物流和交通系主任 Ruth Banomyong 表示，僵局归结为治理方面的根本分歧。

In December, the Bangkok Post reported construction would begin “as planned” in May the next year. “Bangkok Set to Be China’s Rail Hub,” read the headline. (Not Thailand’s rail hub—China’s.) Again, the big day came and went. Over a dozen bilateral meetings have failed to resolve questions over funding, loan conditions, and divisions of labor. Ruth Banomyong, the head of the department of international business, logistics, and transport at Bangkok’s Thammasat University, says the impasse comes down to a fundamental difference in governing.

“在中国，基本上就是我们想做这个项目，所以你必须做，”Banomyong 说。“在泰国，情况稍微复杂一些。你必须经过一系列程序：环境、社会、健康影响评估。你必须考虑财务回报。这些对于中国人的思维方式来说都非常陌生。”例如，中国大部分高铁线路都是亏本运营的。但 Banomyong 了解到，当中国向泰国人发送其为铁路计算的预计回报率时，泰国团队回应说这太低了，只有最低 11% 或 12% 的回报率才能证明该项目的合理性。此后不久，中国数字分析师带着一份新的可行性研究报告回来了，报告显示了新的预计回报率：12.1%。“这是一个非常不同的模式，”Banomyong 说。“一种不同的工作方式。”

“In China, it’s basically a matter of, we want to do this project, so you have to do it,” Banomyong says. “In Thailand, it’s a little more complicated. You have to go through a number of processes: environmental, social, health impact assessments. You have to look at financial returns. This is all very foreign to the Chinese way of thinking.” For instance, China operates most of its own high-speed rail lines at a loss. But Banomyong learned that when China sent the Thais the projected rate of return it had calculated for the railway, the Thai team responded that it was too low, and only a minimum of 11 or 12 percent could justify the project. Shortly thereafter, the Chinese number-crunchers came back with a new feasibility study showing a new projected rate of return: 12.1 percent. “It’s a very different paradigm,” says Banomyong. “A different way of working.”

这些分歧有时会使泰国和中国政府之间的信任紧张，这也是铁路项目多次推迟的原因之一。但更大的原因可能是泰国并不像中国那样需要这条铁路。泰国更感兴趣的是扩大客运服务，而中国虽然大谈泛亚高铁，但主要还是为了运输货物。在东南亚拼图中，泰国是中国绝对不能失去的一块，它是通往新加坡的任何陆路路线上不可避免的组成部分。

These differences have sometimes strained trust between the Thai and Chinese governments, which is part of why the railway project has faced multiple delays. But the bigger reason may be that Thailand simply doesn’t need the railway as much as China does. Thailand is more interested in expanding passenger service, whereas China, for all its talk about a Pan-Asia bullet train, is primarily looking to move freight. And in the Southeast Asia jigsaw puzzle, Thailand is the piece China simply can’t afford to lose—it’s an unavoidable component of any land route to Singapore.

中国还希望通过铁路进入泰国湾地理位置优越的深海港口，尤其是泰中罗勇工业区。该工业区成立于 2006 年，由中国制造业集团华立集团和泰国工业园区开发商 Amata 合资成立。它本质上是重工业的唐人街——工厂的森林城市——遍布中国制造工厂，生产从太阳能电池板到橡胶产品等各种产品。

China also wants rail access to the Gulf of Thailand’s well-placed deep-sea ports, particularly in the Thai-Chinese Rayong Industrial Zone. Established in 2006, the zone is a joint venture between the Holley Group, a Chinese manufacturing conglomerate, and Amata, a Thai developer of industrial parks. It’s essentially a Chinatown for heavy industry—a Forest City for factories—strewn with Chinese manufacturing plants churning out everything from solar panels to rubber products.

罗勇府是泰国东部经济走廊的三个省份之一，用一位利益相关者的话来说，这是一个 5,000 平方英里的“制造业天堂”。中国将东部经济走廊视为一带一路的必经之路。直到最近，该区主要还是电子、汽车和石化企业的基地。但泰国政府希望将东部经济走廊推向价值链的上游，培育机器人、航空、医学和生物燃料等创新驱动型产业。

Rayong is one of three provinces that make up Thailand’s Eastern Economic Corridor, a 5,000-square-mile “manufacturing paradise,” in the words of one stakeholder. China sees the EEC as a One Belt One Road must-have. Until recently, the zone has mostly been a base for electronics, automotive, and petrochemical interests. But the Thai government wants to move the EEC further up the value chain, cultivating innovation-driven industries like robotics, aviation, medical sciences, and biofuels.

为了实现这一目标，政府为东部经济走廊的外国投资者提供了巨大的激励措施，比如无附加条件的九十九年土地租赁和 50% 的公司税减免。这本身并没有错——放宽投资者规则以刺激特定地区的增长正是经济特区的目的。但东部经济走廊提供的激励措施让一些专家感到，它们超出了对泰国有利的底线，甚至超出了泰国法律认为合法的底线。学术上与 EEC 相比另一人警告说，这些淡化了的法规可能会引发一系列外国土地争夺战。

To achieve this, the government is offering huge incentives to foreign investors in the EEC, like few-strings-attached ninety-nine-year land leases and 50 percent deductions on corporate taxes. There’s nothing inherently wrong with this—softening the rules for investors to spur growth in a particular region is exactly what special economic zones are designed to do. But the incentives being offered in the EEC have struck some experts as straining the limits of what’s good for Thailand, or even what’s considered legal under Thai law. One academic compared the EEC to “Hong Kong in the colonial era”—a giveaway to foreign powers. Another warned that the watered-down regulations could spark a string of foreign land grabs.

“在这里，你可以做任何你想做的事，”一位在曼谷一家露天酒吧喝着 Singhas 啤酒的中国游客告诉我。“在中国，压力太大了。你无时无刻不在工作。我认识的每个人似乎都不开心。然后你来到泰国，感觉就像——”他张开双臂，闭上眼睛，将脸转向太阳，微笑着。

“You can do what you want here,” one Chinese tourist draining happy-hour Singhas at an outdoor bar in Bangkok told me. “In China, there’s so much pressure. You work all the time. Everyone I know seems unhappy. Then you come to Thailand and it’s like—” he spreads his arms wide, closes his eyes, turns his face toward the sun and smiles.

在联合国《2017 年世界幸福报告》显示，泰国位列第 32 位，是亚洲排名第二的幸福国家，仅次于新加坡。中国排在第 79 位，略高于巴基斯坦，但比 2012 年有所进步，当时中国排名第 112 位（共 156 个），北京的审查机构禁止发布该报告。

In the UN’s 2017 World Happiness Report, Thailand ranked 32nd on the list, the second-happiest country in Asia after Singapore. China came in 79th, a notch above Pakistan, but an improvement from 2012, when it ranked 112th (out of 156) and Beijing’s censors banned the report.

在此期间，寻求暂时逃离的中国人数量激增。曼谷的几乎所有旅游景点、商场、食品店和免税店都挤满了中国游客。泰国非常愿意欢迎他们，只要他们回国时留下尽可能多的泰铢。从中国南部城市乘飞机只需三个小时就可抵达泰国，泰国有严格的法律，旨在阻止外国人进入泰国抢占工作和房地产。外国人在泰国拥有土地，甚至拥有公寓大楼一半以上的单位都是违法的（因为这会表面上使大楼下面的土地“归外国所有”）。同样，泰国的公司通常每雇用一名外国人就必须雇用四名泰国人。

During this time, the number of Chinese looking for a temporary escape has exploded. Virtually every one of Bangkok’s tourist attractions, malls, food stores, and duty-free shops is awash in Chinese visitors. And Thailand has been more than willing to welcome them, as long as they go back home after leaving behind as much baht as possible. An easy three-hour flight from China’s southern cities, Thailand has strict laws designed to discourage foreigners from coming in and snapping up jobs and real estate. It’s illegal for foreigners to own land in Thailand, or to even own more than half of the units in a condo building (since this would ostensibly make the land beneath the building “foreign-owned.”) Likewise, companies in Thailand generally have to employ four Thais for every foreigner they hire.

在东部经济走廊，不仅这些规则正在放宽，而且前所未有的激励措施正在巩固，以吸引更多来自中国和其他地方的外国人。政府正在向外国人提供该地区某些商业部门的多数股权，并放宽有关长期土地租赁的规定。许多规则的修改是通过援引第 44 条实现的，该条款赋予巴育将军颁布“加强社会团结与和谐”法令的绝对权力。

In the EEC, not only are these rules being relaxed, but unprecedented incentives to lure more foreigners from China and elsewhere are being cemented into place. The government is offering foreigners the right to majority ownership of certain business sectors in the zone and relaxing the rules around long-term land leases. Many of the rule revisions were achieved through the invocation of Article 44, which gives General Prayuth absolute power to make decrees that “strengthen public unity and harmony.”

在这种情况下，第 44 条被以外资的名义援引，这默认了泰国经济已经陷入困境，需要采取严厉措施。2013 年，由于政治不和，经济增长率从 6.5% 暴跌至 2.9%。2014 年，增长率进一步下降，略低于 1%。此后，经济增长率略有回升——2016 年达到 3.2%——但如果经济不稳固，军政府知道其独裁统治很快就会开始失效。

In this case, Article 44 is being invoked in the name of foreign investment, a tacit acknowledgment that Thailand’s economy is troubled enough to merit drastic measures. In 2013, amid political discord, growth plummeted from 6.5 percent to 2.9 percent. In 2014, it fell even further, slipping just below 1 percent. Growth has since inched up—it reached 3.2 percent in 2016—but without a solid economy, the junta knows its autocratic rule could quickly start to wear thin.

执政当局急于刺激经济增长、巩固与北京的关系、并使其继续执掌泰国政府合法化，因此再次向铁路敞开大门。7 月 11 日，2017 年，泰国内阁批准了一项新协议。两国同意利用泰国建筑公司和中国工程建设铁路第一段，最终将连接中国、曼谷和东部经济走廊。泰国将投入 50 多亿美元建设第一阶段，资金将来自国内外——其中可能包括亚投行和中国本身。巴育将军再次援引第 44 条，以放宽对未来可能参与该项目的中国工程师的限制。

Eager to stimulate growth, bolster its standing with Beijing, and legitimize its continued place at the helm of Thailand’s government, the ruling regime is creaking open the door to the railway once again. On July 11, 2017, Thailand’s cabinet approved a new agreement. Using Thai construction firms and Chinese engineering, the countries agreed to build the first segment of a railway that could eventually link China to Bangkok and the EEC. Thailand is putting up over $5 billion to build phase one, money it will source both at home and overseas—including, perhaps, from the AIIB and China itself. General Prayuth again invoked Article 44 to ease restrictions on Chinese engineers who might one day work on the project.

一如既往，中国将该项目定位为所有参与方的三赢项目。泛亚铁路实际上是中国实现东南亚一系列愿望的机制。从供应链到建筑合同、从房地产投资到沿海通道、从外交手段到自然资源，中国在该地区可以挖掘的东西太多了。也许这就是为什么中国多年来忍受着西西弗斯式的挫折，耐心地向前推进，而其南部不守规矩的邻国却一再颠覆其精心制定的计划。如果他们能停止抗议和政治，停止要求环境影响报告和成本效益预测，而是直接加入进来就好了。

As usual, China is framing the project as a win-win-win for all involved. The Pan-Asia Railway is really a mechanism for China to realize an array of desires in Southeast Asia. From supply chains to construction contracts, real estate ventures to coastal access, diplomatic leverage to natural resources, there’s so much for China to mine from the region. Perhaps this is why it’s put up with the Sisyphean setbacks for years, patiently pushing forward as its unruly neighbors to the south repeatedly capsize its carefully laid plans. If only they would stop with the protests and politics, the demands for environmental impact reports and cost-benefit projections, and simply get on board.

结语

Epilogue

退休是一种重塑自我的方式，退休六个月后，宋沙瓦·凌沙瓦在七月的一个阴天星期天来到了蓬帕寺。作为佛教寺庙，蓬帕寺很朴素，是一座小小的桃形八角形寺庙，坐落在琅勃拉邦东部边缘一座不起眼的灌木丛山上。它剥落的外墙油漆已被随意地修补过，但从它的位置可以俯瞰缓缓流淌的南康河和远处新建的国际机场，景色令人叹为观止。

Retirement is a form of reinvention, and six months into his, Somsavat Lengsavad showed up at Wat Phon Phao on a cloudy Sunday in July. As Buddhist temples go, Wat Phon Phao is a modest one, a small peach octagon atop a scrubby, inconspicuous hill near the eastern edge of Luang Prabang. Its flaking exterior paint has been nonchalantly patched over, but its perch commanded an impressive view of the lazy Nam Khan River and the new international airport beyond.

宋沙瓦特在那里接受出家仪式，从他站着的地方，他可以看到老挝航空的涡轮螺旋桨飞机轰隆隆地降落在下面的停机坪上。这位前政治家三年前也曾站在那块停机坪上，他与承建该机场的中国国有企业中工国际工程公司的高管一起主持了机场的竣工仪式。

Somsavat was there to be ordained as a monk, and from where he stood he could watch Lao Airlines turboprops alighting noisily on the tarmac below. The former statesman had stood on that tarmac three years earlier, when he presided over the airport’s completion ceremony with executives from CAMC Engineering, the Chinese state-owned enterprise that built it.

他决定回到家乡的寺院并不奇怪。他今年 71 岁，退休的老挝人政治家们有时会在职业生涯结束时寻求赎罪。宋沙瓦的赎罪比大多数人都更为重要。他发起了一系列事件，让一个庞大的外国实体史无前例地进入这个相对无权无势的小国。当他在政治生涯的非正式结束时进入 Wat Phon Phao 时，数百名工人正在推动泛亚铁路的第一段也是迄今为止唯一一段穿越老挝的路段。对中国来说，这一段很重要，但最终只是一项更大努力的一部分。然而，对老挝来说，这是自越南战争以来该国遭遇的最大灾难。

His decision to return to his hometown monastery wasn’t all that odd. He was seventy-one, and retired Lao politicians sometimes seek atonement at the conclusion of their careers. Somsavat’s had been more consequential than most. He had set in motion a chain of events that had allowed a massive foreign entity unprecedented access to his tiny, relatively powerless nation. As he entered Wat Phon Phao at the unofficial end of his political life, hundreds of workers were pushing the first and so far only segment of the Pan-Asia Railway through Laos. For China, the segment was important, but ultimately a single part of a much larger effort. For Laos, however, it was the biggest thing to crash into the country since the Vietnam War.

“中国似乎有太多的投资，但它需要的投资远远不止这些。”中国城市化历史学家汤姆·米勒在他的著作《 中国十亿城市人口》中这样写道。 要保持增长，中国必须继续建设，如果不是在国内，那么在其他国家。在国内，它正努力应对过度开发。但在国外，它正在开始。目前，中国两大政策性银行的海外贷款中只有约 35% 用于一带一路投资。仍有很大的增长空间。

“China seems to have too much investment, but it needs so much more.” That’s how Chinese urbanization chronicler Tom Miller put it in his book China’s Urban Billion. To keep growing, China must keep building, if not at home then in other countries. Domestically it’s struggled with a glut of development. But beyond its borders it’s just getting started. Only about 35 percent of overseas lending from the country’s two big policy banks is currently going to One Belt One Road investments. There’s still plenty of room to grow.

寻求修建连接东南亚和云南省的铁路网，暗示了中国在推进这一扩张过程中面临的挑战。中国已经证明自己有能力在东南亚建设；它的桥梁、水坝和体育场随处可见。但东南亚是一个动荡的地区，长期充斥着政治动荡、经济动荡、民粹主义狂热和文化摩擦。正是这些因素帮助中国进入东南亚——功能失调、腐败、贫困——还有一些特质，可以将大规模、长期的项目变成没有出口的迷宫。在一定程度上，中国可以将这些条件转化为自己的优势，但对于一个习惯于在高度控制的舒适环境中建设的国家来说，东南亚仍然是一个陌生的地形。在一群自信、不稳定的主权国家之间修建铁路需要重新调整，尤其是当其中一些国家不信任你的动机、害怕你的影响力或讨厌你的经营方式时。

The pursuit of a railway network tethering Southeast Asia to Yunnan Province offers a hint of the challenges China faces in pushing that expansion forward. China has shown it can build in Southeast Asia; its bridges, dams, and stadiums are everywhere. But Southeast Asia is a churning region, chronically awash in political upheaval, economic volatility, populist zeal, and cultural friction. The very qualities that have helped China gain entry—dysfunction, corruption, poverty—are also the qualities that can turn large-scale, long-term projects into mazes with no exit. To a degree, China can turn these conditions to its advantage, but Southeast Asia is still exotic terrain for a country used to building in the hyper-controlled comfort of home. Slicing a railway through an assertive, erratic jumble of sovereign states requires recalibration, particularly when some of those states distrust your motives, fear your influence, or resent the way you do business.

然而，中国有不畏质疑的历史，也正在努力从错误中吸取教训。从历史上看，中国是一个回避结盟、不愿与亲密朋友交往的国家。但作为国际舞台上一个新兴国家，中国别无选择，只能参与其中，而建设基础设施和商业联系是其接触世界的策略。这导致了中国主导的海外发展项目的出现，多年后，一条贯穿马来半岛的铁路网可能会被列入这一成就名单。正如习近平主席在 2017 年“一带一路”论坛开幕致辞中毫不掩饰地说的那样，“发展是解决一切问题的总钥匙”。

China has a history defying its skeptics, however, and it’s trying to learn from its mistakes. Historically, it’s been a kingdom that eschewed alliances and was hesitant to embrace intimate friends. But as a rising player on the international stage, it has little choice but to engage, and building infrastructural and commercial links is the tactic it’s chosen for reaching out to the world. This has resulted in spectacular Chinese-led development projects abroad, and years from now, a rail network running the length of the Malay Peninsula may be included on that roster of achievements. “Development,” as President Xi Jinping unabashedly said in his opening remarks at the Belt and Road Forum in 2017, “holds the master key to solving all problems.”

中国的现实与它向世界展现的形象之间存在着差距。当其经济数据不够令人印象深刻时，政府就会修改数据。它在国际事件中用虚假的外表掩盖贫民窟，粉饰那些不能反映理想中国形象的无害新闻。因此，北京为泛亚铁路披上了尽可能美好的外衣也就不足为奇了，新闻稿、宣传视频以及庆祝其破土动工的仪式。

There’s a gulf between China’s reality and how it depicts itself to the world. When its economic data is insufficiently impressive, the government simply modifies the numbers. It hides its slums behind false facades during international events, and varnishes up the most innocuous bit of news that doesn’t reflect an ideal PRC. So it’s no surprise Beijing has put the best possible face on its Pan-Asia Railway, with press releases, promotional videos, and ceremonial groundbreakings celebrating its dawn.

中国渴望的结果不是从昆明到新加坡的单程车程。这是一个充满中国影响力、联系和控制力的地区。随着中国在东南亚修建高速公路、管道和经济区，泛亚铁路将把世界梦寐以求的地区进一步拉入汉字文化圈。但中国到目前为止的漫长而艰难的旅程凸显了未来艰巨的任务。

The outcome China craves isn’t a one-seat ride from Kunming to Singapore. It’s a region infused with Chinese influence, connections, and control. Along with the highways, pipelines, and economic zones China is establishing across Southeast Asia, a Pan-Asia Railway would draw a coveted part of the world further into the Sinosphere. But China’s long, awkward journey to this point highlights the daunting task that is ahead.

致谢

Acknowledgments

我很早就想写这个故事了，非常感谢 Jimmy So、Nick Lemann、Camille McDuffie 和 Columbia Global Reports 团队的其他成员允许我这样做。尤其是 Jimmy，他总是能提供绝妙的想法和深刻的评论，在喝咖啡、吃越南粉、打乒乓球的间隙，他总是能提供和讨论这些想法和评论。

I’ve wanted to write this story for quite some time, and I’m grateful to Jimmy So, Nick Lemann, Camille McDuffie, and the rest of the team at Columbia Global Reports for allowing me to do so. Jimmy, in particular, was an ever-present source of brilliant ideas and insightful critiques, delivered and debated over cups of coffee, bowls of pho, and rounds of ping-pong.
